segment.source: Deploy Windows 10 in a school (Windows 10)
segment.target: Deploy Windows 10 in a school (Windows 10)

segment.source: Learn how to integrate your school environment with Microsoft Office 365, Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS), and Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).
segment.target: Learn how to integrate your school environment with Microsoft Office 365, Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS), and Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).

segment.source: Deploy Windows 10 and apps to new devices or upgrade existing devices to Windows 10.
segment.target: Deploy Windows 10 and apps to new devices or upgrade existing devices to Windows 10.

segment.source: Manage faculty, students, and devices by using Microsoft Intune and Group Policy.
segment.target: Manage faculty, students, and devices by using Microsoft Intune and Group Policy.

segment.source: Deploy Windows 10 in a school
segment.target: Deploy Windows 10 in a school

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This guide shows you how to deploy the Windows 10 operating system in a school environment.
segment.target: This guide shows you how to deploy the Windows 10 operating system in a school environment.

segment.source: You learn how to deploy Windows 10 in classrooms; integrate the school environment with Microsoft Office 365, Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS), and Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD); and deploy Windows 10 and your apps to new devices or upgrade existing devices to Windows 10.
segment.target: You learn how to deploy Windows 10 in classrooms; integrate the school environment with Microsoft Office 365, Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS), and Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD); and deploy Windows 10 and your apps to new devices or upgrade existing devices to Windows 10.

segment.source: This guide also describes how to use Microsoft Intune and Group Policy to manage devices.
segment.target: This guide also describes how to use Microsoft Intune and Group Policy to manage devices.

segment.source: Finally, the guide discusses common, ongoing maintenance tasks that you will perform after initial deployment as well as the automated tools and built-in features of the operating system.
segment.target: Finally, the guide discusses common, ongoing maintenance tasks that you will perform after initial deployment as well as the automated tools and built-in features of the operating system.

segment.source: Prepare for school deployment
segment.target: Prepare for school deployment

segment.source: Proper preparation is essential for a successful school deployment.
segment.target: Proper preparation is essential for a successful school deployment.

segment.source: To avoid common mistakes, your first step is to plan a typical school configuration.
segment.target: To avoid common mistakes, your first step is to plan a typical school configuration.

segment.source: Just as with building a house, you need a blueprint for what your school should look like when it’s finished.
segment.target: Just as with building a house, you need a blueprint for what your school should look like when it’s finished.

segment.source: The second step in preparation is to learn how you will configure your school.
segment.target: The second step in preparation is to learn how you will configure your school.

segment.source: Just as a builder needs to have the right tools to build a house, you need the right set of tools to deploy your school.
segment.target: Just as a builder needs to have the right tools to build a house, you need the right set of tools to deploy your school.

segment.source: Plan a typical school configuration
segment.target: Plan a typical school configuration

segment.source: As part of preparing for your school deployment, you need to plan your configuration—the focus of this guide.
segment.target: As part of preparing for your school deployment, you need to plan your configuration—the focus of this guide.

segment.source: Figure 1 illustrates a typical finished school configuration that you can use as a model (the blueprint in our builder analogy) for the finished state.
segment.target: Figure 1 illustrates a typical finished school configuration that you can use as a model (the blueprint in our builder analogy) for the finished state.

segment.source: Typical classroom configuration in a school
segment.target: Typical classroom configuration in a school

segment.source: This school configuration has the following characteristics:
segment.target: This school configuration has the following characteristics:

segment.source: It contains one or more admin devices.
segment.target: It contains one or more admin devices.

segment.source: It contains two or more classrooms.
segment.target: It contains two or more classrooms.

segment.source: Each classroom contains one teacher device.
segment.target: Each classroom contains one teacher device.

segment.source: The classrooms connect to each other through multiple subnets.
segment.target: The classrooms connect to each other through multiple subnets.

segment.source: All devices in each classroom connect to a single subnet.
segment.target: All devices in each classroom connect to a single subnet.

segment.source: All devices have high-speed, persistent connections to each other and to the Internet.
segment.target: All devices have high-speed, persistent connections to each other and to the Internet.

segment.source: All teachers and students have access to Windows Store or Windows Store for Business.
segment.target: All teachers and students have access to Windows Store or Windows Store for Business.

segment.source: All devices receive software updates from Intune (or another device management system).
segment.target: All devices receive software updates from Intune (or another device management system).

segment.source: You install a 64-bit version of Windows 10 on the admin device.
segment.target: You install a 64-bit version of Windows 10 on the admin device.

segment.source: You install the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) on the admin device.
segment.target: You install the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) on the admin device.

segment.source: You install the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) on the admin device.
segment.target: You install the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) on the admin device.

segment.source: You install the 64-bit version of the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 2 on the admin device.
segment.target: You install the 64-bit version of the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 2 on the admin device.

segment.source: Note: In this guide, all references to MDT refer to the 64-bit version of MDT 2013 Update 2.
segment.target: Note: In this guide, all references to MDT refer to the 64-bit version of MDT 2013 Update 2.

segment.source: The devices use Azure AD in Office 365 Education for identity management.
segment.target: The devices use Azure AD in Office 365 Education for identity management.

segment.source: If you have on-premises AD DS, you can integrate Azure AD with on-premises AD DS.
segment.target: If you have on-premises AD DS, you can integrate Azure AD with on-premises AD DS.

segment.source: Use Intune, compliance settings in Office 365, or Group Policy in AD DS to manage devices.
segment.target: Use Intune, compliance settings in Office 365, or Group Policy in AD DS to manage devices.

segment.source: Each device supports a one-student-per-device or multiple-students-per-device scenario.
segment.target: Each device supports a one-student-per-device or multiple-students-per-device scenario.

segment.source: The devices can be a mixture of different make, model, and processor architecture (32 bit or 64 bit) or be identical.
segment.target: The devices can be a mixture of different make, model, and processor architecture (32 bit or 64 bit) or be identical.

segment.source: To initiate Windows 10 deployment, use a USB flash drive, DVD-ROM or CD-ROM, or Pre-Boot Execution Environment Boot (PXE Boot).
segment.target: To initiate Windows 10 deployment, use a USB flash drive, DVD-ROM or CD-ROM, or Pre-Boot Execution Environment Boot (PXE Boot).

segment.source: The devices can be a mixture of different Windows 10 editions, such as Windows 10 Home, Windows 10 Pro, and Windows 10 Education.
segment.target: The devices can be a mixture of different Windows 10 editions, such as Windows 10 Home, Windows 10 Pro, and Windows 10 Education.

segment.source: Office 365 Education allows:
segment.target: Office 365 Education allows:

segment.source: Students and faculty to use Microsoft Office Online to create and edit Microsoft Word, OneNote, PowerPoint, and Excel documents in a browser.
segment.target: Students and faculty to use Microsoft Office Online to create and edit Microsoft Word, OneNote, PowerPoint, and Excel documents in a browser.

segment.source: Teachers to use the OneNote Class Notebook app to share content and collaborate with students.
segment.target: Teachers to use the OneNote Class Notebook app to share content and collaborate with students.

segment.source: Faculty to use the OneNote Staff Notebooks app to collaborate with other teachers, administration, and faculty.
segment.target: Faculty to use the OneNote Staff Notebooks app to collaborate with other teachers, administration, and faculty.

segment.source: Teachers to employ Sway to create interactive educational digital storytelling.
segment.target: Teachers to employ Sway to create interactive educational digital storytelling.

segment.source: Students and faculty to use email and calendars, with mailboxes up to 50 GB per user.
segment.target: Students and faculty to use email and calendars, with mailboxes up to 50 GB per user.

segment.source: Faculty to use advanced email features like email archiving and legal hold capabilities.
segment.target: Faculty to use advanced email features like email archiving and legal hold capabilities.

segment.source: Faculty to help prevent unauthorized users from accessing documents and email by using Azure Rights Management.
segment.target: Faculty to help prevent unauthorized users from accessing documents and email by using Azure Rights Management.

segment.source: Faculty to use advanced compliance tools on the unified eDiscovery pages in the Office 365 Compliance Center.
segment.target: Faculty to use advanced compliance tools on the unified eDiscovery pages in the Office 365 Compliance Center.

segment.source: Faculty to host online classes, parent–teacher conferences, and other collaboration in Skype for Business or Skype.
segment.target: Faculty to host online classes, parent–teacher conferences, and other collaboration in Skype for Business or Skype.

segment.source: Students and faculty to access up to 1 TB of personal cloud storage that users inside and outside the educational institution can share through OneDrive for Business.
segment.target: Students and faculty to access up to 1 TB of personal cloud storage that users inside and outside the educational institution can share through OneDrive for Business.

segment.source: Teachers to provide collaboration in the classroom through Microsoft SharePoint Online team sites.
segment.target: Teachers to provide collaboration in the classroom through Microsoft SharePoint Online team sites.

segment.source: Students and faculty to use Office 365 Video to manage videos.
segment.target: Students and faculty to use Office 365 Video to manage videos.

segment.source: Students and faculty to use Yammer to collaborate through private social networking.
segment.target: Students and faculty to use Yammer to collaborate through private social networking.

segment.source: Students and faculty to access classroom resources from anywhere on any device (including Windows 10 Mobile, iOS, and Android devices).
segment.target: Students and faculty to access classroom resources from anywhere on any device (including Windows 10 Mobile, iOS, and Android devices).

segment.source: For more information about Office 365 Education features and a FAQ, go to Office 365 Education.
segment.target: For more information about Office 365 Education features and a FAQ, go to Office 365 Education.

segment.source: How to configure a school
segment.target: How to configure a school

segment.source: Now that you have the plan (blueprint) for your classroom, you’re ready to learn about the tools you will use to deploy it.
segment.target: Now that you have the plan (blueprint) for your classroom, you’re ready to learn about the tools you will use to deploy it.

segment.source: There are many tools you could use to accomplish the task, but this guide focuses on using those tools that require the least infrastructure and technical knowledge.
segment.target: There are many tools you could use to accomplish the task, but this guide focuses on using those tools that require the least infrastructure and technical knowledge.

segment.source: The primary tool you will use to deploy Windows 10 in your school is MDT, which uses Windows ADK components to make deployment easier.
segment.target: The primary tool you will use to deploy Windows 10 in your school is MDT, which uses Windows ADK components to make deployment easier.

segment.source: You could just use the Windows ADK to perform your deployment, but MDT simplifies the process by providing an intuitive, wizard-driven user interface (UI).
segment.target: You could just use the Windows ADK to perform your deployment, but MDT simplifies the process by providing an intuitive, wizard-driven user interface (UI).

segment.source: You can use MDT as a stand-alone tool or integrate it with Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager.
segment.target: You can use MDT as a stand-alone tool or integrate it with Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager.

segment.source: As a stand-alone tool, MDT performs Lite Touch Installation (LTI) deployments—deployments that require minimal infrastructure and allow you to control the level of automation.
segment.target: As a stand-alone tool, MDT performs Lite Touch Installation (LTI) deployments—deployments that require minimal infrastructure and allow you to control the level of automation.

segment.source: When integrated with System Center Configuration Manager, MDT performs Zero Touch Installation (ZTI) deployments, which require more infrastructure (such as System Center Configuration Manager) but result in fully automated deployments.
segment.target: When integrated with System Center Configuration Manager, MDT performs Zero Touch Installation (ZTI) deployments, which require more infrastructure (such as System Center Configuration Manager) but result in fully automated deployments.

segment.source: MDT includes the Deployment Workbench—a console from which you can manage the deployment of Windows 10 and your apps.
segment.target: MDT includes the Deployment Workbench—a console from which you can manage the deployment of Windows 10 and your apps.

segment.source: You configure the deployment process in the Deployment Workbench, including the management of operating systems, device drivers, apps and migration of user settings on existing devices.
segment.target: You configure the deployment process in the Deployment Workbench, including the management of operating systems, device drivers, apps and migration of user settings on existing devices.

segment.source: LTI performs deployment from a deployment share—a network-shared folder on the device where you installed MDT.
segment.target: LTI performs deployment from a deployment share—a network-shared folder on the device where you installed MDT.

segment.source: You can perform over-the-network deployments from the deployment share or perform deployments from a local copy of the deployment share on a USB drive or DVD.
segment.target: You can perform over-the-network deployments from the deployment share or perform deployments from a local copy of the deployment share on a USB drive or DVD.

segment.source: You will learn more about MDT in the Prepare the admin device section.
segment.target: You will learn more about MDT in the Prepare the admin device section.

segment.source: The focus of MDT is deployment, so you also need tools that help you manage your Windows 10 devices and apps.
segment.target: The focus of MDT is deployment, so you also need tools that help you manage your Windows 10 devices and apps.

segment.source: You can manage Windows 10 devices and apps with Intune, the Compliance Management feature in Office 365, or Group Policy in AD DS.
segment.target: You can manage Windows 10 devices and apps with Intune, the Compliance Management feature in Office 365, or Group Policy in AD DS.

segment.source: You can use any combination of these tools based on your school requirements.
segment.target: You can use any combination of these tools based on your school requirements.

segment.source: The configuration process requires the following devices:
segment.target: The configuration process requires the following devices:

segment.source: Admin device.
segment.target: Admin device.

segment.source: This is the device you use for your day-to-day job functions.
segment.target: This is the device you use for your day-to-day job functions.

segment.source: It’s also the one you use to create and manage the Windows 10 and app deployment process.
segment.target: It’s also the one you use to create and manage the Windows 10 and app deployment process.

segment.source: You install the Windows ADK and MDT on this device.
segment.target: You install the Windows ADK and MDT on this device.

segment.source: Faculty devices.
segment.target: Faculty devices.

segment.source: These are the devices that the teachers and other faculty use for their day-to-day job functions.
segment.target: These are the devices that the teachers and other faculty use for their day-to-day job functions.

segment.source: You use the admin device to deploy (or upgrade) Windows 10 and apps to these devices.
segment.target: You use the admin device to deploy (or upgrade) Windows 10 and apps to these devices.

segment.source: Student devices.
segment.target: Student devices.

segment.source: The students will use these devices.
segment.target: The students will use these devices.

segment.source: You will use the admin device deploy (or upgrade) Windows 10 and apps to them.
segment.target: You will use the admin device deploy (or upgrade) Windows 10 and apps to them.

segment.source: The high-level process for deploying and configuring devices within individual classrooms and the school as a whole is as follows and illustrated in Figure 3:
segment.target: The high-level process for deploying and configuring devices within individual classrooms and the school as a whole is as follows and illustrated in Figure 3:

segment.source: Prepare the admin device for use, which includes installing the Windows ADK and MDT.
segment.target: Prepare the admin device for use, which includes installing the Windows ADK and MDT.

segment.source: On the admin device, create and configure the Office 365 Education subscription that you will use for each classroom in the school.
segment.target: On the admin device, create and configure the Office 365 Education subscription that you will use for each classroom in the school.

segment.source: On the admin device, configure integration between on-premises AD DS and Azure AD (if you have an on premises AD DS configuration).
segment.target: On the admin device, configure integration between on-premises AD DS and Azure AD (if you have an on premises AD DS configuration).

segment.source: On the admin device, create and configure a Windows Store for Business portal.
segment.target: On the admin device, create and configure a Windows Store for Business portal.

segment.source: On the admin device, prepare for management of the Windows 10 devices after deployment.
segment.target: On the admin device, prepare for management of the Windows 10 devices after deployment.

segment.source: On the student and faculty devices, deploy Windows 10 to new or existing devices, or upgrade eligible devices to Windows 10.
segment.target: On the student and faculty devices, deploy Windows 10 to new or existing devices, or upgrade eligible devices to Windows 10.

segment.source: On the admin device, manage the Windows 10 devices and apps, the Office 365 subscription, and the AD DS and Azure AD integration.
segment.target: On the admin device, manage the Windows 10 devices and apps, the Office 365 subscription, and the AD DS and Azure AD integration.

segment.source: fig 3
segment.target: fig 3

segment.source: Figure 3.
segment.target: Figure 3.

segment.source: How school configuration works
segment.target: How school configuration works

segment.source: Each of the steps illustrated in Figure 3 directly correspond to the remaining high-level sections in this guide.
segment.target: Each of the steps illustrated in Figure 3 directly correspond to the remaining high-level sections in this guide.

segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: In this section, you looked at the final configuration of your individual classrooms and the school as a whole upon completion of this guide.
segment.target: In this section, you looked at the final configuration of your individual classrooms and the school as a whole upon completion of this guide.

segment.source: You also learned the high-level steps you need to perform to deploy the faculty and student devices in your school.
segment.target: You also learned the high-level steps you need to perform to deploy the faculty and student devices in your school.

segment.source: Prepare the admin device
segment.target: Prepare the admin device

segment.source: Now, you’re ready to prepare the admin device for use in the school.
segment.target: Now, you’re ready to prepare the admin device for use in the school.

segment.source: This process includes installing the Windows ADK, installing the MDT, and creating the MDT deployment share.
segment.target: This process includes installing the Windows ADK, installing the MDT, and creating the MDT deployment share.

segment.source: Install the Windows ADK
segment.target: Install the Windows ADK

segment.source: The first step in preparing the admin device is to install the Windows ADK.
segment.target: The first step in preparing the admin device is to install the Windows ADK.

segment.source: The Windows ADK contains the deployment tools that MDT uses, including the Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE), the Windows User State Migration Tool (USMT), and Deployment Image Servicing and Management.
segment.target: The Windows ADK contains the deployment tools that MDT uses, including the Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE), the Windows User State Migration Tool (USMT), and Deployment Image Servicing and Management.

segment.source: When you install the Windows ADK on the admin device, select the following features:
segment.target: When you install the Windows ADK on the admin device, select the following features:

segment.source: Deployment tools
segment.target: Deployment tools

segment.source: Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE)
segment.target: Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE)

segment.source: User State Migration Tool (USMT)
segment.target: User State Migration Tool (USMT)

segment.source: For more information about installing the Windows ADK, see Step 2-2: Install the Windows ADK.
segment.target: For more information about installing the Windows ADK, see Step 2-2: Install the Windows ADK.

segment.source: Install MDT
segment.target: Install MDT

segment.source: Next, install MDT.
segment.target: Next, install MDT.

segment.source: MDT uses the Windows ADK to help you manage and perform Windows 10 and app deployment and is a free tool available directly from Microsoft.
segment.target: MDT uses the Windows ADK to help you manage and perform Windows 10 and app deployment and is a free tool available directly from Microsoft.

segment.source: You can use MDT to deploy 32-bit or 64-bit versions of Windows 10.
segment.target: You can use MDT to deploy 32-bit or 64-bit versions of Windows 10.

segment.source: Install the 64-bit version of MDT to support deployment of 32-bit and 64-bit operating systems.
segment.target: Install the 64-bit version of MDT to support deployment of 32-bit and 64-bit operating systems.

segment.source: Note: If you install the 32-bit version of MDT, you can install only 32-bit versions of Windows 10.
segment.target: Note: If you install the 32-bit version of MDT, you can install only 32-bit versions of Windows 10.

segment.source: Ensure that you download and install the 64-bit version of MDT so that you can install 64-bit and 32 bit versions of the operating system.
segment.target: Ensure that you download and install the 64-bit version of MDT so that you can install 64-bit and 32 bit versions of the operating system.

segment.source: For more information about installing MDT on the admin device, see Installing a New Instance of MDT.
segment.target: For more information about installing MDT on the admin device, see Installing a New Instance of MDT.

segment.source: Now, you’re ready to create the MDT deployment share and populate it with the operating system, apps, and device drivers you want to deploy to your devices.
segment.target: Now, you’re ready to create the MDT deployment share and populate it with the operating system, apps, and device drivers you want to deploy to your devices.

segment.source: Create a deployment share
segment.target: Create a deployment share

segment.source: MDT includes the Deployment Workbench, a graphical user interface that you can use to manage MDT deployment shares.
segment.target: MDT includes the Deployment Workbench, a graphical user interface that you can use to manage MDT deployment shares.

segment.source: A deployment share is a shared folder that contains all the MDT deployment content.
segment.target: A deployment share is a shared folder that contains all the MDT deployment content.

segment.source: The LTI Deployment Wizard accesses the deployment content over the network or from a local copy of the deployment share (known as MDT deployment media).
segment.target: The LTI Deployment Wizard accesses the deployment content over the network or from a local copy of the deployment share (known as MDT deployment media).

segment.source: For more information about how to create a deployment share, see Step 3-1: Create an MDT Deployment Share.
segment.target: For more information about how to create a deployment share, see Step 3-1: Create an MDT Deployment Share.

segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: In this section, you installed the Windows ADK and MDT on the admin device.
segment.target: In this section, you installed the Windows ADK and MDT on the admin device.

segment.source: You also created the MDT deployment share that you will configure and use later in the LTI deployment process.
segment.target: You also created the MDT deployment share that you will configure and use later in the LTI deployment process.

segment.source: Create and configure Office 365
segment.target: Create and configure Office 365

segment.source: Office 365 is one of the core components of your classroom environment.
segment.target: Office 365 is one of the core components of your classroom environment.

segment.source: You create and manage student identities in Office 365, and students and teachers use the suite as their email, contacts, and calendar system.
segment.target: You create and manage student identities in Office 365, and students and teachers use the suite as their email, contacts, and calendar system.

segment.source: Teachers and students use Office 365 collaboration features such as SharePoint, OneNote, and OneDrive for Business.
segment.target: Teachers and students use Office 365 collaboration features such as SharePoint, OneNote, and OneDrive for Business.

segment.source: As a first step in deploying your classroom, create an Office 365 Education subscription, and then configure Office 365 for the classroom.
segment.target: As a first step in deploying your classroom, create an Office 365 Education subscription, and then configure Office 365 for the classroom.

segment.source: For more information about Office 365 Education deployment, see School deployment of Office 365 Education.
segment.target: For more information about Office 365 Education deployment, see School deployment of Office 365 Education.

segment.source: Select the appropriate Office 365 Education license plan
segment.target: Select the appropriate Office 365 Education license plan

segment.source: Complete the following steps to select the appropriate Office 365 Education license plan for your school:
segment.target: Complete the following steps to select the appropriate Office 365 Education license plan for your school:

segment.source: Determine the number of faculty members and students who will use the classroom.
segment.target: Determine the number of faculty members and students who will use the classroom.

segment.source: Office 365 Education licensing plans are available specifically for faculty and students.
segment.target: Office 365 Education licensing plans are available specifically for faculty and students.

segment.source: You must assign faculty and students the correct licensing plan.
segment.target: You must assign faculty and students the correct licensing plan.

segment.source: Determine the faculty members and students who need to install Office applications on devices (if any).
segment.target: Determine the faculty members and students who need to install Office applications on devices (if any).

segment.source: Faculty and students can use Office applications online (standard plans) or run them locally (Office 365 ProPlus plans).
segment.target: Faculty and students can use Office applications online (standard plans) or run them locally (Office 365 ProPlus plans).

segment.source: Table 1 lists the advantages and disadvantages of standard and Office 365 ProPlus plans.
segment.target: Table 1 lists the advantages and disadvantages of standard and Office 365 ProPlus plans.

segment.target: Table 1.

segment.target: Comparison of standard and Microsoft Office 365 ProPlus plans

segment.target: Plan

segment.target: Advantages

segment.source: Disadvantages
segment.target: Disadvantages

segment.source: Standard
segment.target: Standard

segment.source: Less expensive than Office 365 ProPlus
segment.target: Less expensive than Office 365 ProPlus

segment.source: Can be run from any device
segment.target: Can be run from any device

segment.source: No installation necessary
segment.target: No installation necessary

segment.source: Must have an Internet connection to use it
segment.target: Must have an Internet connection to use it

segment.source: Does not support all the features found in Office 365 ProPlus
segment.target: Does not support all the features found in Office 365 ProPlus

segment.target: Office ProPlus

segment.target: Only requires an Internet connection every 30 days (for activation)

segment.target: Supports full set of Office features

segment.target: Can be installed on only five devices per user (there is no limit to the number of devices on which you can run Office apps online)

segment.source: The best user experience is to run Office 365 ProPlus or use native Office apps on mobile devices.
segment.target: The best user experience is to run Office 365 ProPlus or use native Office apps on mobile devices.

segment.source: If neither of these options is available, use Office applications online.
segment.target: If neither of these options is available, use Office applications online.

segment.source: In addition, all Office 365 plans provide a better user experience by storing documents in OneDrive for Business, which is included in all Office 365 plans.
segment.target: In addition, all Office 365 plans provide a better user experience by storing documents in OneDrive for Business, which is included in all Office 365 plans.

segment.source: OneDrive for Business keeps content in sync among devices and helps ensure that users always have access to their documents on any device.
segment.target: OneDrive for Business keeps content in sync among devices and helps ensure that users always have access to their documents on any device.

segment.source: Determine whether students or faculty need Azure Rights Management.
segment.target: Determine whether students or faculty need Azure Rights Management.

segment.source: You can use Azure Rights Management to protect classroom information against unauthorized access.
segment.target: You can use Azure Rights Management to protect classroom information against unauthorized access.

segment.source: Azure Rights Management protects your information inside or outside the classroom through encryption, identity, and authorization policies, securing your files and email.
segment.target: Azure Rights Management protects your information inside or outside the classroom through encryption, identity, and authorization policies, securing your files and email.

segment.source: You can retain control of the information, even when it’s shared with people outside the classroom or your educational institution.
segment.target: You can retain control of the information, even when it’s shared with people outside the classroom or your educational institution.

segment.source: Azure Rights Management is free to use with all Office 365 Education license plans.
segment.target: Azure Rights Management is free to use with all Office 365 Education license plans.

segment.source: For more information, see Azure Rights Management.
segment.target: For more information, see Azure Rights Management.

segment.target: Record the Office 365 Education license plans needed for the classroom in Table 2.

segment.target: You will use the Office 365 Education license plan information you record in Table 2 in the Create user accounts in Office 365 section of this guide.

segment.source: Create a new Office 365 Education subscription
segment.target: Create a new Office 365 Education subscription

segment.source: To create a new Office 365 Education subscription for use in the classroom, use your educational institution’s email account.
segment.target: To create a new Office 365 Education subscription for use in the classroom, use your educational institution’s email account.

segment.source: There are no costs to you or to students for signing up for Office 365 Education subscriptions.
segment.target: There are no costs to you or to students for signing up for Office 365 Education subscriptions.

segment.source: Note: If you already have an Office 365 Education subscription, you can use that subscription and continue to the next section, Add domains and subdomains.
segment.target: Note: If you already have an Office 365 Education subscription, you can use that subscription and continue to the next section, Add domains and subdomains.

segment.source: To create a new Office 365 subscription
segment.target: To create a new Office 365 subscription

segment.source: In Microsoft Edge or Internet Explorer, type in the address bar.
segment.target: In Microsoft Edge or Internet Explorer, type in the address bar.

segment.source: Note If you have already used your current sign-in account to create a new Office 365 subscription, you will be prompted to sign in.
segment.target: Note If you have already used your current sign-in account to create a new Office 365 subscription, you will be prompted to sign in.

segment.source: If you want to create a new Office 365 subscription, start an In-Private Window in one of the following:
segment.target: If you want to create a new Office 365 subscription, start an In-Private Window in one of the following:

segment.source: Microsoft Edge by opening the Microsoft Edge app, either pressing Ctrl+Shift+P or clicking or tapping More actions, and then clicking or tapping New InPrivate window.
segment.target: Microsoft Edge by opening the Microsoft Edge app, either pressing Ctrl+Shift+P or clicking or tapping More actions, and then clicking or tapping New InPrivate window.

segment.source: Internet Explorer 11 by opening Internet Explorer 11, either pressing Ctrl+Shift+P or clicking or tapping Settings, clicking or tapping Safety, and then clicking or tapping InPrivate Browsing.
segment.target: Internet Explorer 11 by opening Internet Explorer 11, either pressing Ctrl+Shift+P or clicking or tapping Settings, clicking or tapping Safety, and then clicking or tapping InPrivate Browsing.

segment.source: On the Get started page, type your school email address in the Enter your school email address box, and then click Sign up.
segment.target: On the Get started page, type your school email address in the Enter your school email address box, and then click Sign up.

segment.source: You will receive an email in your school email account.
segment.target: You will receive an email in your school email account.

segment.source: Click the hyperlink in the email in your school email account.
segment.target: Click the hyperlink in the email in your school email account.

segment.source: On the One last thing page, complete your user information, and then click Start.
segment.target: On the One last thing page, complete your user information, and then click Start.

segment.source: The wizard creates your new Office 365 Education subscription, and you are automatically signed in as the administrative user you specified when you created the subscription.
segment.target: The wizard creates your new Office 365 Education subscription, and you are automatically signed in as the administrative user you specified when you created the subscription.

segment.source: Add domains and subdomains
segment.target: Add domains and subdomains

segment.source: Now that you have created your new Office 365 Education subscription, add the domains and subdomains that your institution uses.
segment.target: Now that you have created your new Office 365 Education subscription, add the domains and subdomains that your institution uses.

segment.source: For example, if your institution has contoso.edu as the primary domain name but you have subdomains for students or faculty (such as students.contoso.edu and faculty.contoso.edu), then you need to add the subdomains.
segment.target: For example, if your institution has contoso.edu as the primary domain name but you have subdomains for students or faculty (such as students.contoso.edu and faculty.contoso.edu), then you need to add the subdomains.

segment.source: To add additional domains and subdomains
segment.target: To add additional domains and subdomains

segment.source: In the Office 365 admin center, in the list view, click DOMAINS.
segment.target: In the Office 365 admin center, in the list view, click DOMAINS.

segment.source: In the details pane, above the list of domains, on the menu bar, click Add domain.
segment.target: In the details pane, above the list of domains, on the menu bar, click Add domain.

segment.source: In the Add a New Domain in Office 365 Wizard, on the Verify domain wizard page, click Let’s get started.
segment.target: In the Add a New Domain in Office 365 Wizard, on the Verify domain wizard page, click Let’s get started.

segment.source: On the Verify domain wizard page, in the Enter a domain you already own box, type your domain name, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Verify domain wizard page, in the Enter a domain you already own box, type your domain name, and then click Next.

segment.source: Sign in to your domain name management provider (for example, Network Solutions or GoDaddy), and then complete the steps for your provider.
segment.target: Sign in to your domain name management provider (for example, Network Solutions or GoDaddy), and then complete the steps for your provider.

segment.source: Repeat these steps for each domain and subdomain you want faculty and students to use for your institution.
segment.target: Repeat these steps for each domain and subdomain you want faculty and students to use for your institution.

segment.source: Configure automatic tenant join
segment.target: Configure automatic tenant join

segment.source: To make it easier for faculty and students to join your Office 365 Education subscription (or tenant), allow them to automatically sign up to your tenant (automatic tenant join).
segment.target: To make it easier for faculty and students to join your Office 365 Education subscription (or tenant), allow them to automatically sign up to your tenant (automatic tenant join).

segment.source: In automatic tenant join, when a faculty member or student signs up for Office 365, Office 365 automatically adds (joins) the user to your Office 365 tenant.
segment.target: In automatic tenant join, when a faculty member or student signs up for Office 365, Office 365 automatically adds (joins) the user to your Office 365 tenant.

segment.source: Note: By default, automatic tenant join is enabled in Office 365 Education, with the exception of certain areas in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa.
segment.target: Note: By default, automatic tenant join is enabled in Office 365 Education, with the exception of certain areas in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa.

segment.source: These countries require opt-in steps to add new users to existing Office 365 tenants.
segment.target: These countries require opt-in steps to add new users to existing Office 365 tenants.

segment.source: Check your country requirements to determine the automatic tenant join default configuration.
segment.target: Check your country requirements to determine the automatic tenant join default configuration.

segment.source: Also, if you use Azure AD Connect, then automatic tenant join is disabled.
segment.target: Also, if you use Azure AD Connect, then automatic tenant join is disabled.

segment.source: Office 365 uses the domain portion of the user’s email address to know which Office 365 tenant to join.
segment.target: Office 365 uses the domain portion of the user’s email address to know which Office 365 tenant to join.

segment.source: For example, if a faculty member or student provides an email address of user@contoso.edu, then Office 365 automatically performs one of the following tasks:
segment.target: For example, if a faculty member or student provides an email address of user@contoso.edu, then Office 365 automatically performs one of the following tasks:

segment.source: If an Office 365 tenant with that domain name (contoso.edu) exists, Office 365 automatically adds the user to that tenant.
segment.target: If an Office 365 tenant with that domain name (contoso.edu) exists, Office 365 automatically adds the user to that tenant.

segment.source: If an Office 365 tenant with that domain name (contoso.edu) does not exists, Office 365 automatically creates a new Office 365 tenant with that domain name and adds the user to it.
segment.target: If an Office 365 tenant with that domain name (contoso.edu) does not exists, Office 365 automatically creates a new Office 365 tenant with that domain name and adds the user to it.

segment.source: You will always want faculty and students to join the Office 365 tenant that you created.
segment.target: You will always want faculty and students to join the Office 365 tenant that you created.

segment.source: Ensure that you perform the steps in the Create a new Office 365 Education subscription and Add domains and subdomains sections before allowing other faculty and students to join Office 365.
segment.target: Ensure that you perform the steps in the Create a new Office 365 Education subscription and Add domains and subdomains sections before allowing other faculty and students to join Office 365.

segment.source: Note: You cannot merge multiple tenants, so any faculty or students who create their own tenant will need to abandon their existing tenant and join yours.
segment.target: Note: You cannot merge multiple tenants, so any faculty or students who create their own tenant will need to abandon their existing tenant and join yours.

segment.source: All new Office 365 Education subscriptions have automatic tenant join enabled by default, but you can enable or disable automatic tenant join by using the Windows PowerShell commands in Table 3.
segment.target: All new Office 365 Education subscriptions have automatic tenant join enabled by default, but you can enable or disable automatic tenant join by using the Windows PowerShell commands in Table 3.

segment.source: For more information about how to run these commands, see How can I prevent students from joining my existing Office 365 tenant.
segment.target: For more information about how to run these commands, see How can I prevent students from joining my existing Office 365 tenant.

segment.source: Table 3.
segment.target: Table 3.

segment.source: Windows PowerShell commands to enable or disable Automatic Tenant Join
segment.target: Windows PowerShell commands to enable or disable Automatic Tenant Join

segment.source: Action
segment.target: Action

segment.source: Windows PowerShell command
segment.target: Windows PowerShell command

segment.source: Enable
segment.target: Enable

segment.source: Disable
segment.target: Disable

segment.source: Note: If your institution has AD DS, then disable automatic tenant join.
segment.target: Note: If your institution has AD DS, then disable automatic tenant join.

segment.source: Instead, use Azure AD integration with AD DS to add users to your Office 365 tenant.
segment.target: Instead, use Azure AD integration with AD DS to add users to your Office 365 tenant.

segment.source: Disable automatic licensing
segment.target: Disable automatic licensing

segment.source: To reduce your administrative effort, automatically assign Office 365 Education or Office 365 Education Plus licenses to faculty and students when they sign up (automatic licensing).
segment.target: To reduce your administrative effort, automatically assign Office 365 Education or Office 365 Education Plus licenses to faculty and students when they sign up (automatic licensing).

segment.source: Automatic licensing also enables Office 365 Education or Office 365 Education Plus features that do not require administrative approval.
segment.target: Automatic licensing also enables Office 365 Education or Office 365 Education Plus features that do not require administrative approval.

segment.source: Note: By default, automatic licensing is enabled in Office 365 Education.
segment.target: Note: By default, automatic licensing is enabled in Office 365 Education.

segment.source: If you want to use automatic licensing, then skip this section and go to the next section.
segment.target: If you want to use automatic licensing, then skip this section and go to the next section.

segment.source: Although all new Office 365 Education subscriptions have automatic licensing enabled by default, you can enable or disable it for your Office 365 tenant by using the Windows PowerShell commands in Table 4.
segment.target: Although all new Office 365 Education subscriptions have automatic licensing enabled by default, you can enable or disable it for your Office 365 tenant by using the Windows PowerShell commands in Table 4.

segment.source: For more information about how to run these commands, see How can I prevent students from joining my existing Office 365 tenant.
segment.target: For more information about how to run these commands, see How can I prevent students from joining my existing Office 365 tenant.

segment.source: Table 4.
segment.target: Table 4.

segment.target: Windows PowerShell commands to enable or disable automatic licensing

segment.target: Action

segment.target: Windows PowerShell command

segment.target: Enable

segment.source: Disable
segment.target: Disable

segment.source: Enable Azure AD Premium
segment.target: Enable Azure AD Premium

segment.source: When you create your Office 365 subscription, you create an Office 365 tenant that includes an Azure AD directory.
segment.target: When you create your Office 365 subscription, you create an Office 365 tenant that includes an Azure AD directory.

segment.source: Azure AD is the centralized repository for all your student and faculty accounts in Office 365, Intune, and other Azure AD–integrated apps.
segment.target: Azure AD is the centralized repository for all your student and faculty accounts in Office 365, Intune, and other Azure AD–integrated apps.

segment.source: Azure AD is available in Free, Basic, and Premium editions.
segment.target: Azure AD is available in Free, Basic, and Premium editions.

segment.source: Azure AD Free, which is included in Office 365 Education, has fewer features than Azure AD Basic, which in turn has fewer features than Azure AD Premium.
segment.target: Azure AD Free, which is included in Office 365 Education, has fewer features than Azure AD Basic, which in turn has fewer features than Azure AD Premium.

segment.source: Educational institutions can obtain Azure AD Basic edition licenses at no cost.
segment.target: Educational institutions can obtain Azure AD Basic edition licenses at no cost.

segment.source: After you obtain your licenses, activate your Azure AD access by completing the steps in Step 3: Activate your Azure Active Directory access.
segment.target: After you obtain your licenses, activate your Azure AD access by completing the steps in Step 3: Activate your Azure Active Directory access.

segment.source: The Azure AD Premium features that are not in Azure AD Basic include:
segment.target: The Azure AD Premium features that are not in Azure AD Basic include:

segment.source: Allow designated users to manage group membership
segment.target: Allow designated users to manage group membership

segment.source: Dynamic group membership based on user metadata
segment.target: Dynamic group membership based on user metadata

segment.source: Multifactor authentication (MFA)
segment.target: Multifactor authentication (MFA)

segment.source: Identify cloud apps that your users run
segment.target: Identify cloud apps that your users run

segment.source: Automatic enrollment in a mobile device management (MDM) system (such as Intune)
segment.target: Automatic enrollment in a mobile device management (MDM) system (such as Intune)

segment.source: Self-service recovery of BitLocker
segment.target: Self-service recovery of BitLocker

segment.source: Add local administrator accounts to Windows 10 devices
segment.target: Add local administrator accounts to Windows 10 devices

segment.source: Azure AD Connect health monitoring
segment.target: Azure AD Connect health monitoring

segment.source: Extended reporting capabilities
segment.target: Extended reporting capabilities

segment.source: You can assign Azure AD Premium licenses to the users who need these features.
segment.target: You can assign Azure AD Premium licenses to the users who need these features.

segment.source: For example, you may want the users who have access to confidential student information to use MFA.
segment.target: For example, you may want the users who have access to confidential student information to use MFA.

segment.source: In this example, you could assign Azure AD Premium to only those users.
segment.target: In this example, you could assign Azure AD Premium to only those users.

segment.source: You can sign up for Azure AD Premium, and then assign licenses to users.
segment.target: You can sign up for Azure AD Premium, and then assign licenses to users.

segment.source: In this section, you sign up for Azure AD Premium.
segment.target: In this section, you sign up for Azure AD Premium.

segment.source: You will assign Azure AD Premium licenses to users later in the deployment process.
segment.target: You will assign Azure AD Premium licenses to users later in the deployment process.

segment.source: For more information about:
segment.target: For more information about:

segment.source: Azure AD editions and the features in each, see Azure Active Directory editions.
segment.target: Azure AD editions and the features in each, see Azure Active Directory editions.

segment.source: How to enable Azure AD premium, see Associate an Azure AD directory with a new Azure subscription.
segment.target: How to enable Azure AD premium, see Associate an Azure AD directory with a new Azure subscription.

segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: You provision and initially configure Office 365 Education as part of the initial configuration.
segment.target: You provision and initially configure Office 365 Education as part of the initial configuration.

segment.source: With the subscription in place, automatic tenant join configured, automatic licensing established, and Azure AD Premium enabled (if required), you’re ready to select the method you will use to create user accounts in Office 365.
segment.target: With the subscription in place, automatic tenant join configured, automatic licensing established, and Azure AD Premium enabled (if required), you’re ready to select the method you will use to create user accounts in Office 365.

segment.source: Select an Office 365 user account–creation method
segment.target: Select an Office 365 user account–creation method

segment.source: Now that you have an Office 365 subscription, you need to determine how you will create your Office 365 user accounts.
segment.target: Now that you have an Office 365 subscription, you need to determine how you will create your Office 365 user accounts.

segment.source: Use the following methods to create Office 365 user accounts:
segment.target: Use the following methods to create Office 365 user accounts:

segment.source: Method 1: Automatically synchronize your on-premises AD DS domain with Azure AD.
segment.target: Method 1: Automatically synchronize your on-premises AD DS domain with Azure AD.

segment.source: Select this method if you have an on-premises AD DS domain.
segment.target: Select this method if you have an on-premises AD DS domain.

segment.source: Method 2: Bulk-import the user accounts from a .csv file (based on information from other sources) into Azure AD.
segment.target: Method 2: Bulk-import the user accounts from a .csv file (based on information from other sources) into Azure AD.

segment.source: Select this method if you don’t have an on-premises AD DS domain.
segment.target: Select this method if you don’t have an on-premises AD DS domain.

segment.source: Method 1: Automatic synchronization between AD DS and Azure AD
segment.target: Method 1: Automatic synchronization between AD DS and Azure AD

segment.source: In this method, you have an on-premises AD DS domain.
segment.target: In this method, you have an on-premises AD DS domain.

segment.source: As shown in Figure 4, the Azure AD Connector tool automatically synchronizes AD DS with Azure AD.
segment.target: As shown in Figure 4, the Azure AD Connector tool automatically synchronizes AD DS with Azure AD.

segment.source: When you add or change any user accounts in AD DS, the Azure AD Connector tool automatically updates Azure AD.
segment.target: When you add or change any user accounts in AD DS, the Azure AD Connector tool automatically updates Azure AD.

segment.source: Note: Azure AD Connect also supports synchronization from any Lightweight Directory Access Protocol version 3 (LDAPv3)–compliant directory by using the information provided in Generic LDAP Connector for FIM 2010 R2 Technical Reference.
segment.target: Note: Azure AD Connect also supports synchronization from any Lightweight Directory Access Protocol version 3 (LDAPv3)–compliant directory by using the information provided in Generic LDAP Connector for FIM 2010 R2 Technical Reference.

segment.source: fig 4
segment.target: fig 4

segment.source: Figure 4.
segment.target: Figure 4.

segment.source: Automatic synchronization between AD DS and Azure AD
segment.target: Automatic synchronization between AD DS and Azure AD

segment.source: For more information about how to perform this step, see the Integrate on-premises AD DS with Azure AD section in this guide.
segment.target: For more information about how to perform this step, see the Integrate on-premises AD DS with Azure AD section in this guide.

segment.source: Method 2: Bulk import into Azure AD from a .csv file
segment.target: Method 2: Bulk import into Azure AD from a .csv file

segment.source: In this method, you have no on-premises AD DS domain.
segment.target: In this method, you have no on-premises AD DS domain.

segment.source: As shown in Figure 5, you manually prepare a .csv file with the student information from your source, and then manually import the information directly into Azure AD.
segment.target: As shown in Figure 5, you manually prepare a .csv file with the student information from your source, and then manually import the information directly into Azure AD.

segment.source: The .csv file must be in the format that Office 365 specifies.
segment.target: The .csv file must be in the format that Office 365 specifies.

segment.source: fig 5
segment.target: fig 5

segment.source: Figure 5.
segment.target: Figure 5.

segment.source: Bulk import into Azure AD from other sources
segment.target: Bulk import into Azure AD from other sources

segment.source: To implement this method, perform the following steps:
segment.target: To implement this method, perform the following steps:

segment.source: Export the student information from the source.
segment.target: Export the student information from the source.

segment.source: Ultimately, you want to format the student information in the format the bulk-import feature requires.
segment.target: Ultimately, you want to format the student information in the format the bulk-import feature requires.

segment.source: Bulk-import the student information into Azure AD.
segment.target: Bulk-import the student information into Azure AD.

segment.source: For more information about how to perform this step, see the Bulk-import user accounts into Office 365 section.
segment.target: For more information about how to perform this step, see the Bulk-import user accounts into Office 365 section.

segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: In this section, you selected the method for creating user accounts in your Office 365 subscription.
segment.target: In this section, you selected the method for creating user accounts in your Office 365 subscription.

segment.source: Ultimately, these user accounts are in Azure AD (which is the identity management system for Office 365).
segment.target: Ultimately, these user accounts are in Azure AD (which is the identity management system for Office 365).

segment.source: Now, you’re ready to create your Office 365 accounts.
segment.target: Now, you’re ready to create your Office 365 accounts.

segment.source: Integrate on-premises AD DS with Azure AD
segment.target: Integrate on-premises AD DS with Azure AD

segment.source: You can integrate your on-premises AD DS domain with Azure AD to provide identity management for your Office 365 tenant.
segment.target: You can integrate your on-premises AD DS domain with Azure AD to provide identity management for your Office 365 tenant.

segment.source: With this integration, you can synchronize the users, security groups, and distribution lists in your AD DS domain with Azure AD with the Azure AD Connect tool.
segment.target: With this integration, you can synchronize the users, security groups, and distribution lists in your AD DS domain with Azure AD with the Azure AD Connect tool.

segment.source: Users will be able to sign in to Office 365 automatically by using their email account and the same password they use to sign in to AD DS.
segment.target: Users will be able to sign in to Office 365 automatically by using their email account and the same password they use to sign in to AD DS.

segment.source: Note: If your institution does not have an on-premises AD DS domain, you can skip this section.
segment.target: Note: If your institution does not have an on-premises AD DS domain, you can skip this section.

segment.source: Select synchronization model
segment.target: Select synchronization model

segment.source: Before you deploy AD DS and Azure AD synchronization, you need to determine where you want to deploy the server that runs Azure AD Connect.
segment.target: Before you deploy AD DS and Azure AD synchronization, you need to determine where you want to deploy the server that runs Azure AD Connect.

segment.source: You can deploy the Azure AD Connect tool by using one of the following methods:
segment.target: You can deploy the Azure AD Connect tool by using one of the following methods:

segment.source: On premises.
segment.target: On premises.

segment.source: As shown in Figure 6, Azure AD Connect runs on premises, which has the advantage of not requiring a virtual private network (VPN) connection to Azure.
segment.target: As shown in Figure 6, Azure AD Connect runs on premises, which has the advantage of not requiring a virtual private network (VPN) connection to Azure.

segment.source: It does, however, require a virtual machine (VM) or physical server.
segment.target: It does, however, require a virtual machine (VM) or physical server.

segment.source: fig 6
segment.target: fig 6

segment.source: Figure 6.
segment.target: Figure 6.

segment.source: Azure AD Connect on premises
segment.target: Azure AD Connect on premises

segment.source: In Azure.
segment.target: In Azure.

segment.source: As shown in Figure 7, Azure AD Connect runs on a VM in Azure AD, which has the advantages of being faster to provision (than a physical, on-premises server), offers better site availability, and helps reduce the number of on-premises servers.
segment.target: As shown in Figure 7, Azure AD Connect runs on a VM in Azure AD, which has the advantages of being faster to provision (than a physical, on-premises server), offers better site availability, and helps reduce the number of on-premises servers.

segment.source: The disadvantage is that you need to deploy a VPN gateway on premises.
segment.target: The disadvantage is that you need to deploy a VPN gateway on premises.

segment.source: fig 7
segment.target: fig 7

segment.source: Figure 7.
segment.target: Figure 7.

segment.source: Azure AD Connect in Azure
segment.target: Azure AD Connect in Azure

segment.source: This guide describes how to run Azure AD Connect on premises.
segment.target: This guide describes how to run Azure AD Connect on premises.

segment.source: For information about running Azure AD Connect in Azure, see Deploy Office 365 Directory Synchronization (DirSync) in Microsoft Azure.
segment.target: For information about running Azure AD Connect in Azure, see Deploy Office 365 Directory Synchronization (DirSync) in Microsoft Azure.

segment.source: Deploy Azure AD Connect on premises
segment.target: Deploy Azure AD Connect on premises

segment.source: In this synchronization model (illustrated in Figure 6), you run Azure AD Connect on premises on a physical device or VM.
segment.target: In this synchronization model (illustrated in Figure 6), you run Azure AD Connect on premises on a physical device or VM.

segment.source: Azure AD Connect synchronizes AD DS user and group accounts with Azure AD.
segment.target: Azure AD Connect synchronizes AD DS user and group accounts with Azure AD.

segment.source: Azure AD Connect includes a wizard that helps you configure Azure AD Connect for your AD DS domain and Office 365 subscription.
segment.target: Azure AD Connect includes a wizard that helps you configure Azure AD Connect for your AD DS domain and Office 365 subscription.

segment.source: First, you install Azure AD Connect; then, you run the wizard to configure it for your institution.
segment.target: First, you install Azure AD Connect; then, you run the wizard to configure it for your institution.

segment.source: To deploy AD DS and Azure AD synchronization
segment.target: To deploy AD DS and Azure AD synchronization

segment.source: Configure your environment to meet the prerequisites for installing Azure AD Connect by performing the steps in Prerequisites for Azure AD Connect.
segment.target: Configure your environment to meet the prerequisites for installing Azure AD Connect by performing the steps in Prerequisites for Azure AD Connect.

segment.source: On the VM or physical device that will run Azure AD Connect, sign in with a domain administrator account.
segment.target: On the VM or physical device that will run Azure AD Connect, sign in with a domain administrator account.

segment.source: Install Azure AD Connect by performing the steps in Install Azure AD Connect.
segment.target: Install Azure AD Connect by performing the steps in Install Azure AD Connect.

segment.source: Configure Azure AD Connect features based on your institution’s requirements by performing the steps in Configure features.
segment.target: Configure Azure AD Connect features based on your institution’s requirements by performing the steps in Configure features.

segment.source: Now that you have used on premises Azure AD Connect to deploy AD DS and Azure AD synchronization, you’re ready to verify that Azure AD Connect is synchronizing AD DS user and group accounts with Azure AD.
segment.target: Now that you have used on premises Azure AD Connect to deploy AD DS and Azure AD synchronization, you’re ready to verify that Azure AD Connect is synchronizing AD DS user and group accounts with Azure AD.

segment.source: Verify synchronization
segment.target: Verify synchronization

segment.source: Azure AD Connect should start synchronization immediately.
segment.target: Azure AD Connect should start synchronization immediately.

segment.source: Depending on the number of users in your AD DS domain, the synchronization process can take some time.
segment.target: Depending on the number of users in your AD DS domain, the synchronization process can take some time.

segment.source: To monitor the process, view the number of AD DS users and groups the tool has synchronized with Azure AD in the Office 365 admin console.
segment.target: To monitor the process, view the number of AD DS users and groups the tool has synchronized with Azure AD in the Office 365 admin console.

segment.source: To verify AD DS and Azure AD synchronization
segment.target: To verify AD DS and Azure AD synchronization

segment.source: Open https://portal.office.com in your web browser.
segment.target: Open https://portal.office.com in your web browser.

segment.source: Using the administrative account that you created in the Create a new Office 365 Education subscription section, sign in to Office 365.
segment.target: Using the administrative account that you created in the Create a new Office 365 Education subscription section, sign in to Office 365.

segment.source: In the list view, expand USERS, and then click Active Users.
segment.target: In the list view, expand USERS, and then click Active Users.

segment.source: In the details pane, view the list of users.
segment.target: In the details pane, view the list of users.

segment.source: The list of users should mirror the users in AD DS.
segment.target: The list of users should mirror the users in AD DS.

segment.source: In the list view, click GROUPS.
segment.target: In the list view, click GROUPS.

segment.source: In the details pane, view the list of security groups.
segment.target: In the details pane, view the list of security groups.

segment.source: The list of users should mirror the security groups in AD DS.
segment.target: The list of users should mirror the security groups in AD DS.

segment.source: In the details pane, double-click one of the security groups.
segment.target: In the details pane, double-click one of the security groups.

segment.source: The list of security group members should mirror the group membership for the corresponding security group in AD DS.
segment.target: The list of security group members should mirror the group membership for the corresponding security group in AD DS.

segment.source: Close the browser.
segment.target: Close the browser.

segment.source: Now that you have verified Azure AD Connect synchronization, you’re ready to assign user licenses for Azure AD Premium.
segment.target: Now that you have verified Azure AD Connect synchronization, you’re ready to assign user licenses for Azure AD Premium.

segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: In this section, you selected your synchronization model, deployed Azure AD Connect, and verified that Azure AD is synchronizing properly.
segment.target: In this section, you selected your synchronization model, deployed Azure AD Connect, and verified that Azure AD is synchronizing properly.

segment.source: Bulk-import user and group accounts into AD DS
segment.target: Bulk-import user and group accounts into AD DS

segment.source: You can bulk-import user and group accounts into your on-premises AD DS domain.
segment.target: You can bulk-import user and group accounts into your on-premises AD DS domain.

segment.source: Bulk-importing accounts helps reduce the time and effort needed to create users compared to creating the accounts manually in the Office 365 Admin portal.
segment.target: Bulk-importing accounts helps reduce the time and effort needed to create users compared to creating the accounts manually in the Office 365 Admin portal.

segment.source: First, you select the appropriate method for bulk-importing user accounts into AD DS.
segment.target: First, you select the appropriate method for bulk-importing user accounts into AD DS.

segment.source: Next, you create the .csv file that contains the user accounts.
segment.target: Next, you create the .csv file that contains the user accounts.

segment.target: Create a source file that contains the user and group accounts

segment.target: After you have selected your user and group account bulk import method, you’re ready to create the source file that contains the user and group account.

segment.source: You’ll use the source file as the input to the import process.
segment.target: You’ll use the source file as the input to the import process.

segment.source: The source file format depends on the method you selected.
segment.target: The source file format depends on the method you selected.

segment.target: The steps for importing the file are slightly different for each method.

segment.target: Note: Bulk-import your group accounts first, and then import your user accounts.

segment.source: Importing in this order allows you to specify group membership when you import your user accounts.
segment.target: Importing in this order allows you to specify group membership when you import your user accounts.
