segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: In this section, you selected the bulk-import method, created the source file that contains the user and group accounts, and imported the user and group accounts in to AD DS.
segment.target: In this section, you selected the bulk-import method, created the source file that contains the user and group accounts, and imported the user and group accounts in to AD DS.

segment.source: If you have Azure AD Connect, it automatically synchronizes the new AD DS user and group accounts to Azure AD.
segment.target: If you have Azure AD Connect, it automatically synchronizes the new AD DS user and group accounts to Azure AD.

segment.source: Now, you’re ready to assign user licenses for Azure AD Premium in the Assign user licenses for Azure AD Premium section later in this guide.
segment.target: Now, you’re ready to assign user licenses for Azure AD Premium in the Assign user licenses for Azure AD Premium section later in this guide.

segment.source: Bulk-import user accounts into Office 365
segment.target: Bulk-import user accounts into Office 365

segment.source: You can bulk-import user and group accounts directly into Office 365, reducing the time and effort required to create users.
segment.target: You can bulk-import user and group accounts directly into Office 365, reducing the time and effort required to create users.

segment.source: First, you bulk-import the user accounts into Office 365.
segment.target: First, you bulk-import the user accounts into Office 365.

segment.source: Then, you create the security groups for your institution.
segment.target: Then, you create the security groups for your institution.

segment.source: Finally, you create the email distribution groups your institution requires.
segment.target: Finally, you create the email distribution groups your institution requires.

segment.source: Create user accounts in Office 365
segment.target: Create user accounts in Office 365

segment.source: Now that you have created your new Office 365 Education subscription, you need to create user accounts.
segment.target: Now that you have created your new Office 365 Education subscription, you need to create user accounts.

segment.source: You can add user accounts for the teachers, other faculty, and students who will use the classroom.
segment.target: You can add user accounts for the teachers, other faculty, and students who will use the classroom.

segment.source: You can use the Office 365 admin center to add individual Office 365 accounts manually—a reasonable process when you’re adding only a few users.
segment.target: You can use the Office 365 admin center to add individual Office 365 accounts manually—a reasonable process when you’re adding only a few users.

segment.source: If you have many users, however, you can automate the process by creating a list of those users, and then use that list to create user accounts (that is, bulk-add users).
segment.target: If you have many users, however, you can automate the process by creating a list of those users, and then use that list to create user accounts (that is, bulk-add users).

segment.source: The bulk-add process assigns the same Office 365 Education license plan to all users on the list.
segment.target: The bulk-add process assigns the same Office 365 Education license plan to all users on the list.

segment.source: Therefore, you must create a separate list for each license plan you recorded in Table 2.
segment.target: Therefore, you must create a separate list for each license plan you recorded in Table 2.

segment.source: Depending on the number of faculty members who need to use the classroom, you may want to add the faculty Office 365 accounts manually; however, use the bulk-add process to add student accounts.
segment.target: Depending on the number of faculty members who need to use the classroom, you may want to add the faculty Office 365 accounts manually; however, use the bulk-add process to add student accounts.

segment.source: For more information about how to bulk-add users to Office 365, see Add several users at the same time to Office 365.
segment.target: For more information about how to bulk-add users to Office 365, see Add several users at the same time to Office 365.

segment.source: Note: If you encountered errors during bulk add, resolve them before you continue the bulk-add process.
segment.target: Note: If you encountered errors during bulk add, resolve them before you continue the bulk-add process.

segment.source: You can view the log file to see which users caused the errors, and then modify the .csv file to correct the problems.
segment.target: You can view the log file to see which users caused the errors, and then modify the .csv file to correct the problems.

segment.source: Click Back to retry the verification process.
segment.target: Click Back to retry the verification process.

segment.source: The email accounts are assigned temporary passwords upon creation.
segment.target: The email accounts are assigned temporary passwords upon creation.

segment.source: You must communicate these temporary passwords to your users before they can sign in to Office 365.
segment.target: You must communicate these temporary passwords to your users before they can sign in to Office 365.

segment.source: Create Office 365 security groups
segment.target: Create Office 365 security groups

segment.source: Assign SharePoint Online resource permissions to Office 365 security groups, not individual user accounts.
segment.target: Assign SharePoint Online resource permissions to Office 365 security groups, not individual user accounts.

segment.source: For example, create one security group for faculty members and another for students.
segment.target: For example, create one security group for faculty members and another for students.

segment.source: Then, you can assign unique SharePoint Online resource permissions to faculty members and a different set of permissions to students.
segment.target: Then, you can assign unique SharePoint Online resource permissions to faculty members and a different set of permissions to students.

segment.source: Add or remove users from the security groups to grant or revoke access to SharePoint Online resources.
segment.target: Add or remove users from the security groups to grant or revoke access to SharePoint Online resources.

segment.source: Note: If your institution has AD DS, don’t create security accounts in Office 365.
segment.target: Note: If your institution has AD DS, don’t create security accounts in Office 365.

segment.source: Instead, create the security groups in AD DS, and then use Azure AD integration to synchronize the security groups with your Office 365 tenant.
segment.target: Instead, create the security groups in AD DS, and then use Azure AD integration to synchronize the security groups with your Office 365 tenant.

segment.source: For information about creating security groups, see Create and manage Office 365 groups in Admin Center Preview.
segment.target: For information about creating security groups, see Create and manage Office 365 groups in Admin Center Preview.

segment.source: You can add and remove users from security groups at any time.
segment.target: You can add and remove users from security groups at any time.

segment.source: Note: Office 365 evaluates group membership when users sign in.
segment.target: Note: Office 365 evaluates group membership when users sign in.

segment.source: If you change group membership for a user, that user may need to sign out, and then sign in again for the change to take effect.
segment.target: If you change group membership for a user, that user may need to sign out, and then sign in again for the change to take effect.

segment.source: Create email distribution groups
segment.target: Create email distribution groups

segment.source: Microsoft Exchange Online uses an email distribution group as a single email recipient for multiple users.
segment.target: Microsoft Exchange Online uses an email distribution group as a single email recipient for multiple users.

segment.source: For example, you could create an email distribution group that contains all students.
segment.target: For example, you could create an email distribution group that contains all students.

segment.source: Then, you could send a message to the email distribution group instead of individually addressing the message to each student.
segment.target: Then, you could send a message to the email distribution group instead of individually addressing the message to each student.

segment.source: You can create email distribution groups based on job role (such as teachers, administration, or students) or specific interests (such as robotics, drama club, or soccer team).
segment.target: You can create email distribution groups based on job role (such as teachers, administration, or students) or specific interests (such as robotics, drama club, or soccer team).

segment.source: You can create any number of distribution groups, and users can be members of more than one group.
segment.target: You can create any number of distribution groups, and users can be members of more than one group.

segment.source: Note: Office 365 can take some time to complete the Exchange Online creation process.
segment.target: Note: Office 365 can take some time to complete the Exchange Online creation process.

segment.source: You will have to wait until Office 365 completes the Exchange Online creation process before you can perform the following steps.
segment.target: You will have to wait until Office 365 completes the Exchange Online creation process before you can perform the following steps.

segment.source: For information about how to create security groups, see Create and manage Office 365 groups in Admin Center Preview.
segment.target: For information about how to create security groups, see Create and manage Office 365 groups in Admin Center Preview.

segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: Now, you have bulk-imported the user accounts into Office 365.
segment.target: Now, you have bulk-imported the user accounts into Office 365.

segment.source: First, you selected the bulk-import method.
segment.target: First, you selected the bulk-import method.

segment.source: Next, you created the Office 365 security groups in Office 365.
segment.target: Next, you created the Office 365 security groups in Office 365.

segment.source: Finally, you created the Office 365 email distribution groups.
segment.target: Finally, you created the Office 365 email distribution groups.

segment.source: Now, you’re ready to assign user licenses for Azure AD Premium.
segment.target: Now, you’re ready to assign user licenses for Azure AD Premium.

segment.source: Assign user licenses for Azure AD Premium
segment.target: Assign user licenses for Azure AD Premium

segment.source: Azure AD is available in Free, Basic, and Premium editions.
segment.target: Azure AD is available in Free, Basic, and Premium editions.

segment.source: Azure AD Free, which is included in Office 365 Education, has fewer features than Azure AD Basic, which in turn has fewer features than Azure AD Premium.
segment.target: Azure AD Free, which is included in Office 365 Education, has fewer features than Azure AD Basic, which in turn has fewer features than Azure AD Premium.

segment.source: Educational institutions can obtain Azure AD Basic licenses at no cost and Azure AD Premium licenses at a reduced cost.
segment.target: Educational institutions can obtain Azure AD Basic licenses at no cost and Azure AD Premium licenses at a reduced cost.

segment.source: You can assign Azure AD Premium licenses to the users who need the features this edition offers.
segment.target: You can assign Azure AD Premium licenses to the users who need the features this edition offers.

segment.source: For example, you may want the users who have access to confidential student information to use MFA.
segment.target: For example, you may want the users who have access to confidential student information to use MFA.

segment.source: In this example, you could assign Azure AD Premium only to those users.
segment.target: In this example, you could assign Azure AD Premium only to those users.

segment.source: For more information about:
segment.target: For more information about:

segment.source: Azure AD editions, see Azure Active Directory editions.
segment.target: Azure AD editions, see Azure Active Directory editions.

segment.source: How to assign user licenses for Azure AD Premium, see How to assign EMS/Azure AD Premium licenses to user accounts.
segment.target: How to assign user licenses for Azure AD Premium, see How to assign EMS/Azure AD Premium licenses to user accounts.

segment.source: Create and configure a Windows Store for Business portal
segment.target: Create and configure a Windows Store for Business portal

segment.source: Windows Store for Business allows you to create your own private portal to manage Windows Store apps in your institution.
segment.target: Windows Store for Business allows you to create your own private portal to manage Windows Store apps in your institution.

segment.source: With Windows Store for Business, you can do the following:
segment.target: With Windows Store for Business, you can do the following:

segment.source: Find and acquire Windows Store apps.
segment.target: Find and acquire Windows Store apps.

segment.source: Manage apps, app licenses, and updates.
segment.target: Manage apps, app licenses, and updates.

segment.source: Distribute apps to your users.
segment.target: Distribute apps to your users.

segment.source: For more information about Windows Store for Business, see Windows Store for Business overview.
segment.target: For more information about Windows Store for Business, see Windows Store for Business overview.

segment.source: The following section shows you how to create a Windows Store for Business portal and configure it for your school.
segment.target: The following section shows you how to create a Windows Store for Business portal and configure it for your school.

segment.source: Create and configure your Windows Store for Business portal
segment.target: Create and configure your Windows Store for Business portal

segment.source: To create and configure your Windows Store for Business portal, simply use the administrative account for your Office 365 subscription to sign in to Windows Store for Business.
segment.target: To create and configure your Windows Store for Business portal, simply use the administrative account for your Office 365 subscription to sign in to Windows Store for Business.

segment.source: Windows Store for Business automatically creates a portal for your institution and uses your account as its administrator.
segment.target: Windows Store for Business automatically creates a portal for your institution and uses your account as its administrator.

segment.source: To create and configure a Windows Store for Business portal
segment.target: To create and configure a Windows Store for Business portal

segment.source: In Microsoft Edge or Internet Explorer, type in the address bar.
segment.target: In Microsoft Edge or Internet Explorer, type in the address bar.

segment.source: On the Windows Store for Business page, click Sign in with an organizational account.
segment.target: On the Windows Store for Business page, click Sign in with an organizational account.

segment.source: Note: If your institution has AD DS, then don’t create security accounts in Office 365.
segment.target: Note: If your institution has AD DS, then don’t create security accounts in Office 365.

segment.source: Instead, create the security groups in AD DS, and then use Azure AD integration to synchronize the security groups with your Office 365 tenant.
segment.target: Instead, create the security groups in AD DS, and then use Azure AD integration to synchronize the security groups with your Office 365 tenant.

segment.source: On the Windows Store for Business sign-in page, use the administrative account for the Office 365 subscription you created in the Create a new Office 365 Education subscription section to sign in.
segment.target: On the Windows Store for Business sign-in page, use the administrative account for the Office 365 subscription you created in the Create a new Office 365 Education subscription section to sign in.

segment.source: On the Windows Store for Business Services Agreement page, review the agreement, select the I accept this agreement and certify that I have the authority to bind my organization to its terms check box, and then click Accept
segment.target: On the Windows Store for Business Services Agreement page, review the agreement, select the I accept this agreement and certify that I have the authority to bind my organization to its terms check box, and then click Accept

segment.source: In the Welcome to the Windows Store for Business dialog box, click OK.
segment.target: In the Welcome to the Windows Store for Business dialog box, click OK.

segment.source: After you create the Windows Store for Business portal, configure it by using the commands in the settings menu listed in Table 7.
segment.target: After you create the Windows Store for Business portal, configure it by using the commands in the settings menu listed in Table 7.

segment.source: Depending on your institution, you may (or may not) need to change these settings to further customize your portal.
segment.target: Depending on your institution, you may (or may not) need to change these settings to further customize your portal.

segment.source: Table 7.
segment.target: Table 7.

segment.source: Menu selections to configure Windows Store for Business settings
segment.target: Menu selections to configure Windows Store for Business settings

segment.source: Menu selection
segment.target: Menu selection

segment.source: What you can do in this menu
segment.target: What you can do in this menu

segment.source: Account information
segment.target: Account information

segment.source: Displays information about your Windows Store for Business account (no settings can be changed).
segment.target: Displays information about your Windows Store for Business account (no settings can be changed).

segment.source: You make changes to this information in Office 365 or the Azure Portal.
segment.target: You make changes to this information in Office 365 or the Azure Portal.

segment.source: For more information, see Update Windows Store for Business account settings.
segment.target: For more information, see Update Windows Store for Business account settings.

segment.source: Device Guard signing
segment.target: Device Guard signing

segment.source: Allows you to upload and sign Device Guard catalog and policy files.
segment.target: Allows you to upload and sign Device Guard catalog and policy files.

segment.source: For more information about Device Guard, see Device Guard deployment guide.
segment.target: For more information about Device Guard, see Device Guard deployment guide.

segment.source: LOB publishers
segment.target: LOB publishers

segment.source: Allows you to add line-of-business (LOB) publishers that can then publish apps to your private store.
segment.target: Allows you to add line-of-business (LOB) publishers that can then publish apps to your private store.

segment.source: LOB publishers are usually internal developers or software vendors that are working with your institution.
segment.target: LOB publishers are usually internal developers or software vendors that are working with your institution.

segment.source: For more information, see Working with line-of-business apps.
segment.target: For more information, see Working with line-of-business apps.

segment.source: Management tools
segment.target: Management tools

segment.source: Allows you to add tools that you can use to distribute (deploy) apps in your private store.
segment.target: Allows you to add tools that you can use to distribute (deploy) apps in your private store.

segment.source: For more information, see Distribute apps with a management tool.
segment.target: For more information, see Distribute apps with a management tool.

segment.source: Offline licensing
segment.target: Offline licensing

segment.source: Allows you to show (or not show) offline licensed apps to people shopping in your private store.
segment.target: Allows you to show (or not show) offline licensed apps to people shopping in your private store.

segment.source: For more information, see Licensing model: online and offline licenses.
segment.target: For more information, see Licensing model: online and offline licenses.

segment.source: Permissions
segment.target: Permissions

segment.source: Allows you to grant other users in your organization the ability to buy, manage, and administer your Windows Store for Business portal.
segment.target: Allows you to grant other users in your organization the ability to buy, manage, and administer your Windows Store for Business portal.

segment.source: You can also remove permissions you have previously granted.
segment.target: You can also remove permissions you have previously granted.

segment.source: For more information, see Roles and permissions in Windows Store for Business.
segment.target: For more information, see Roles and permissions in Windows Store for Business.

segment.source: Private store
segment.target: Private store

segment.source: Allows you to change the organization name used in your Windows Store for Business portal.
segment.target: Allows you to change the organization name used in your Windows Store for Business portal.

segment.source: When you create your portal, the private store uses the organization name that you used to create your Office 365 subscription.
segment.target: When you create your portal, the private store uses the organization name that you used to create your Office 365 subscription.

segment.source: For more information, see Distribute apps using your private store.
segment.target: For more information, see Distribute apps using your private store.

segment.source: Find, acquire, and distribute apps in the portal
segment.target: Find, acquire, and distribute apps in the portal

segment.source: Now that you have created your Windows Store for Business portal, you’re ready to find, acquire, and distribute apps that you will add to your portal.
segment.target: Now that you have created your Windows Store for Business portal, you’re ready to find, acquire, and distribute apps that you will add to your portal.

segment.source: You do this by using the Inventory page in Windows Store for Business.
segment.target: You do this by using the Inventory page in Windows Store for Business.

segment.source: Note: Your educational institution can now use a credit card or purchase order to pay for apps in Windows Store for Business.
segment.target: Note: Your educational institution can now use a credit card or purchase order to pay for apps in Windows Store for Business.

segment.source: You can deploy apps to individual users or make apps available to users through your private store.
segment.target: You can deploy apps to individual users or make apps available to users through your private store.

segment.source: Deploying apps to individual users restricts the app to those specified users.
segment.target: Deploying apps to individual users restricts the app to those specified users.

segment.source: Making apps available through your private store allows all your users.
segment.target: Making apps available through your private store allows all your users.

segment.source: For more information about how to find, acquire, and distribute apps in the portal, see App inventory management for Windows Store for Business.
segment.target: For more information about how to find, acquire, and distribute apps in the portal, see App inventory management for Windows Store for Business.

segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: At the end of this section, you should have a properly configured Windows Store for Business portal.
segment.target: At the end of this section, you should have a properly configured Windows Store for Business portal.

segment.source: You have also found and acquired your apps from Windows Store.
segment.target: You have also found and acquired your apps from Windows Store.

segment.source: Finally, you should have deployed all your Windows Store apps to your users.
segment.target: Finally, you should have deployed all your Windows Store apps to your users.

segment.source: Now, you’re ready to deploy Windows Store apps to your users.
segment.target: Now, you’re ready to deploy Windows Store apps to your users.

segment.source: Plan for deployment
segment.target: Plan for deployment

segment.source: You will use the LTI deployment process in MDT to deploy Windows 10 to devices or to upgrade devices to Windows 10.
segment.target: You will use the LTI deployment process in MDT to deploy Windows 10 to devices or to upgrade devices to Windows 10.

segment.source: Prior to preparing for deployment, you must make some deployment planning decisions, including selecting the operating systems you will use, the approach you will use to create your Windows 10 images, and the method you will use to initiate the LTI deployment process.
segment.target: Prior to preparing for deployment, you must make some deployment planning decisions, including selecting the operating systems you will use, the approach you will use to create your Windows 10 images, and the method you will use to initiate the LTI deployment process.

segment.source: Select the operating systems
segment.target: Select the operating systems

segment.source: Later in the process, you will import the versions of Windows 10 you want to deploy.
segment.target: Later in the process, you will import the versions of Windows 10 you want to deploy.

segment.source: You can deploy the operating system to new devices, refresh existing devices, or upgrade existing devices.
segment.target: You can deploy the operating system to new devices, refresh existing devices, or upgrade existing devices.

segment.source: In the case of:
segment.target: In the case of:

segment.source: New devices or refreshing existing devices, you will complete replace the existing operating system on a device with Windows 10.
segment.target: New devices or refreshing existing devices, you will complete replace the existing operating system on a device with Windows 10.

segment.source: Upgrading existing devices, you will upgrade the existing operating system (the Windows 8.1 or Windows 7 operating system) to Windows 10.
segment.target: Upgrading existing devices, you will upgrade the existing operating system (the Windows 8.1 or Windows 7 operating system) to Windows 10.

segment.source: Depending on your school’s requirements, you may need any combination of the following Windows 10 editions:
segment.target: Depending on your school’s requirements, you may need any combination of the following Windows 10 editions:

segment.source: Windows 10 Home.
segment.target: Windows 10 Home.

segment.source: Use this operating system to upgrade existing eligible institution-owned and personal devices that are running Windows 8.1 Home or Windows 7 Home to Windows 10 Home.
segment.target: Use this operating system to upgrade existing eligible institution-owned and personal devices that are running Windows 8.1 Home or Windows 7 Home to Windows 10 Home.

segment.source: Windows 10 Pro.
segment.target: Windows 10 Pro.

segment.source: Use this operating system to:
segment.target: Use this operating system to:

segment.source: Upgrade existing eligible institution-owned and personal devices running Windows 8.1 Pro or Windows 7 Professional to Windows 10 Pro.
segment.target: Upgrade existing eligible institution-owned and personal devices running Windows 8.1 Pro or Windows 7 Professional to Windows 10 Pro.

segment.source: Deploy new instances of Windows 10 Pro to devices so that new devices have a known configuration.
segment.target: Deploy new instances of Windows 10 Pro to devices so that new devices have a known configuration.

segment.source: Windows 10 Education.
segment.target: Windows 10 Education.

segment.source: Use this operating system to:
segment.target: Use this operating system to:

segment.source: Upgrade institution-owned devices to Windows 10 Education.
segment.target: Upgrade institution-owned devices to Windows 10 Education.

segment.source: Deploy new instances of Windows 10 Education so that new devices have a known configuration.
segment.target: Deploy new instances of Windows 10 Education so that new devices have a known configuration.

segment.source: Note: Although you can use Windows 10 Home on institution-owned devices, Microsoft recommends that you use Windows 10 Pro or Windows 10 Education, instead.
segment.target: Note: Although you can use Windows 10 Home on institution-owned devices, Microsoft recommends that you use Windows 10 Pro or Windows 10 Education, instead.

segment.source: Windows 10 Pro and Windows 10 Education provide support for MDM, policy-based management, and Windows Store for Business.
segment.target: Windows 10 Pro and Windows 10 Education provide support for MDM, policy-based management, and Windows Store for Business.

segment.source: These features are not available in Windows 10 Home.
segment.target: These features are not available in Windows 10 Home.

segment.source: One other consideration is the mix of processor architectures you will support.
segment.target: One other consideration is the mix of processor architectures you will support.

segment.source: If you can, support only 64-bit versions of Windows 10.
segment.target: If you can, support only 64-bit versions of Windows 10.

segment.source: If you have devices that can run only 32 bit versions of Windows 10, you will need to import both 64-bit and 32-bit versions of the Windows 10 editions listed above.
segment.target: If you have devices that can run only 32 bit versions of Windows 10, you will need to import both 64-bit and 32-bit versions of the Windows 10 editions listed above.

segment.source: Note: On devices that have minimal system resources (such as devices with only 2 GB of memory or 32 GB of storage), use 32-bit versions of Windows 10 because 64-bit versions of Windows 10 place more stress on device system resources.
segment.target: Note: On devices that have minimal system resources (such as devices with only 2 GB of memory or 32 GB of storage), use 32-bit versions of Windows 10 because 64-bit versions of Windows 10 place more stress on device system resources.

segment.source: Finally, as a best practice, minimize the number of operating systems that you deploy and manage.
segment.target: Finally, as a best practice, minimize the number of operating systems that you deploy and manage.

segment.source: If possible, standardize institution-owned devices on one Windows 10 edition (such as a 64-bit version of Windows 10 Education or Windows 10 Pro).
segment.target: If possible, standardize institution-owned devices on one Windows 10 edition (such as a 64-bit version of Windows 10 Education or Windows 10 Pro).

segment.source: Of course, you cannot standardize personal devices on a specific operating system version or processor architecture.
segment.target: Of course, you cannot standardize personal devices on a specific operating system version or processor architecture.

segment.source: Select an image approach
segment.target: Select an image approach

segment.source: A key operating system image decision is whether to use a “thin” or “thick” image.
segment.target: A key operating system image decision is whether to use a “thin” or “thick” image.

segment.source: Thin images contain only the operating system, and MDT installs the necessary device drivers and apps after the operating system has been installed.
segment.target: Thin images contain only the operating system, and MDT installs the necessary device drivers and apps after the operating system has been installed.

segment.source: Thick images contain the operating system, “core” apps (such as Office), and device drivers.
segment.target: Thick images contain the operating system, “core” apps (such as Office), and device drivers.

segment.source: With thick images, MDT installs any device drivers and apps not included in the thick image after the operating system has been installed.
segment.target: With thick images, MDT installs any device drivers and apps not included in the thick image after the operating system has been installed.

segment.source: The advantage to a thin image is that the final deployment configuration is dynamic, and you can easily change the configuration without having to capture another image.
segment.target: The advantage to a thin image is that the final deployment configuration is dynamic, and you can easily change the configuration without having to capture another image.

segment.source: The disadvantage of a thin image is that it takes longer to complete the deployment.
segment.target: The disadvantage of a thin image is that it takes longer to complete the deployment.

segment.source: The advantage of a thick image is that the deployment takes less time than it would for a thin image.
segment.target: The advantage of a thick image is that the deployment takes less time than it would for a thin image.

segment.source: The disadvantage of a thick image is that you need to capture a new image each time you want to make a change to the operating system, apps, or other software in the image.
segment.target: The disadvantage of a thick image is that you need to capture a new image each time you want to make a change to the operating system, apps, or other software in the image.

segment.source: Select a method to initiate deployment
segment.target: Select a method to initiate deployment

segment.source: The MDT deployment process is highly automated, requiring minimal information to deploy or upgrade Windows 10, but you must manually initiate the MDT deployment process.
segment.target: The MDT deployment process is highly automated, requiring minimal information to deploy or upgrade Windows 10, but you must manually initiate the MDT deployment process.

segment.source: To do so, use the method listed in Table 8 that best meets the needs of your institution.
segment.target: To do so, use the method listed in Table 8 that best meets the needs of your institution.

segment.source: Table 8.
segment.target: Table 8.

segment.source: Methods to initiate MDT deployment
segment.target: Methods to initiate MDT deployment

segment.source: Method
segment.target: Method

segment.source: Description and reason to select this method
segment.target: Description and reason to select this method

segment.source: Windows Deployment Services
segment.target: Windows Deployment Services

segment.source: This method:
segment.target: This method:

segment.source: Uses diskless booting to initiate MDT deployment.
segment.target: Uses diskless booting to initiate MDT deployment.

segment.source: Works only with devices that support PXE boot.
segment.target: Works only with devices that support PXE boot.

segment.source: Deploys Windows 10 over the network, which consumes more network bandwidth than deployment from local media.
segment.target: Deploys Windows 10 over the network, which consumes more network bandwidth than deployment from local media.

segment.source: Deploys images more slowly than when using local media.
segment.target: Deploys images more slowly than when using local media.

segment.source: Requires that you deploy a Windows Deployment Services server.
segment.target: Requires that you deploy a Windows Deployment Services server.

segment.source: Select this method when you want to deploy Windows over-the-network and perform diskless booting.
segment.target: Select this method when you want to deploy Windows over-the-network and perform diskless booting.

segment.source: The advantage of this method is that the diskless media are generic and typically don’t require updates after you create them (the Deployment Wizard accesses the centrally located deployment share over the network).
segment.target: The advantage of this method is that the diskless media are generic and typically don’t require updates after you create them (the Deployment Wizard accesses the centrally located deployment share over the network).

segment.source: The disadvantage of this method is that over-the-network deployments are slower than deployments from local media, and you must deploy a Windows Deployment Services server.
segment.target: The disadvantage of this method is that over-the-network deployments are slower than deployments from local media, and you must deploy a Windows Deployment Services server.

segment.source: Bootable media
segment.target: Bootable media

segment.source: This method:
segment.target: This method:

segment.source: Initiates MDT deployment by booting from local media, including from USB drives, DVD-ROM, or CD-ROM.
segment.target: Initiates MDT deployment by booting from local media, including from USB drives, DVD-ROM, or CD-ROM.

segment.source: Deploys Windows 10 over the network, which consumes more network bandwidth than deployment from local media.
segment.target: Deploys Windows 10 over the network, which consumes more network bandwidth than deployment from local media.

segment.source: Deploys images more slowly than when using local media.
segment.target: Deploys images more slowly than when using local media.

segment.source: Requires no additional infrastructure.
segment.target: Requires no additional infrastructure.

segment.source: Select this method when you want to deploy Windows over-the-network and are willing to boot the target device from local media.
segment.target: Select this method when you want to deploy Windows over-the-network and are willing to boot the target device from local media.

segment.source: The advantage of this method is that the media are generic and typically don’t require updates after you create them (the Deployment Wizard accesses the centrally located deployment share over the network).
segment.target: The advantage of this method is that the media are generic and typically don’t require updates after you create them (the Deployment Wizard accesses the centrally located deployment share over the network).

segment.source: The disadvantage of this method is that over-the-network deployments are slower than deployment from local media.
segment.target: The disadvantage of this method is that over-the-network deployments are slower than deployment from local media.

segment.source: MDT deployment media
segment.target: MDT deployment media

segment.source: This method:
segment.target: This method:

segment.source: Initiates MDT deployment by booting from a local USB hard disk.
segment.target: Initiates MDT deployment by booting from a local USB hard disk.

segment.source: Deploys Windows 10 from local media, which consumes less network bandwidth than over-the-network methods.
segment.target: Deploys Windows 10 from local media, which consumes less network bandwidth than over-the-network methods.

segment.source: Deploys images more quickly than network-based methods do.
segment.target: Deploys images more quickly than network-based methods do.

segment.source: Requires a USB hard disk because of the deployment share’s storage requirements (up to 100 GB).
segment.target: Requires a USB hard disk because of the deployment share’s storage requirements (up to 100 GB).

segment.source: Select this method when you want to perform local deployments and are willing to boot the target device from a local USB hard disk.
segment.target: Select this method when you want to perform local deployments and are willing to boot the target device from a local USB hard disk.

segment.source: The advantage of this method is that local deployments are faster than over-the-network deployments.
segment.target: The advantage of this method is that local deployments are faster than over-the-network deployments.

segment.source: The disadvantage of this method is that each time you change the deployment share, you must regenerate the MDT deployment media and update the USB hard disk.
segment.target: The disadvantage of this method is that each time you change the deployment share, you must regenerate the MDT deployment media and update the USB hard disk.

segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: At the end of this section, you should know the Windows 10 editions and processor architecture that you want to deploy (and will import later in the process).
segment.target: At the end of this section, you should know the Windows 10 editions and processor architecture that you want to deploy (and will import later in the process).

segment.source: You also determined whether you want to use thin or thick images.
segment.target: You also determined whether you want to use thin or thick images.

segment.source: Finally, you selected the method for initiating your LTI deployment.
segment.target: Finally, you selected the method for initiating your LTI deployment.

segment.source: Now, you can prepare for Windows 10 deployment.
segment.target: Now, you can prepare for Windows 10 deployment.

segment.source: Prepare for deployment
segment.target: Prepare for deployment

segment.source: To deploy Windows 10 to devices, using the LTI deployment method in MDT.
segment.target: To deploy Windows 10 to devices, using the LTI deployment method in MDT.

segment.source: In this section, you prepare your MDT environment and Windows Deployment Services for Windows 10 deployment.
segment.target: In this section, you prepare your MDT environment and Windows Deployment Services for Windows 10 deployment.

segment.source: Configure the MDT deployment share
segment.target: Configure the MDT deployment share

segment.source: The first step in preparation for Windows 10 deployment is to configure—that is, populate—the MDT deployment share.
segment.target: The first step in preparation for Windows 10 deployment is to configure—that is, populate—the MDT deployment share.

segment.source: Table 9 lists the MDT deployment share configuration tasks that you must perform.
segment.target: Table 9 lists the MDT deployment share configuration tasks that you must perform.

segment.source: Perform the tasks in the order represented in Table 9.
segment.target: Perform the tasks in the order represented in Table 9.

segment.source: Table 9.
segment.target: Table 9.

segment.source: Tasks to configure the MDT deployment share
segment.target: Tasks to configure the MDT deployment share

segment.source: Task
segment.target: Task

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Import operating systems
segment.target: Import operating systems

segment.source: Import the operating systems that you selected in the Select operating systems section into the deployment share.
segment.target: Import the operating systems that you selected in the Select operating systems section into the deployment share.

segment.source: For more information about how to import operating systems, see Import an Operating System into the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: For more information about how to import operating systems, see Import an Operating System into the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: Import device drives
segment.target: Import device drives

segment.source: Device drivers allow Windows 10 to know a device’s hardware resources and connected hardware accessories.
segment.target: Device drivers allow Windows 10 to know a device’s hardware resources and connected hardware accessories.

segment.source: Without the proper device drivers, certain features may be unavailable.
segment.target: Without the proper device drivers, certain features may be unavailable.

segment.source: For example, without the proper audio driver, a device cannot play sounds; without the proper camera driver, the device cannot take photos or use video chat.
segment.target: For example, without the proper audio driver, a device cannot play sounds; without the proper camera driver, the device cannot take photos or use video chat.

segment.source: Import device drivers for each device in your institution.
segment.target: Import device drivers for each device in your institution.

segment.source: For more information about how to import device drivers, see Import Device Drivers into the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: For more information about how to import device drivers, see Import Device Drivers into the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: Create MDT applications for Windows Store apps
segment.target: Create MDT applications for Windows Store apps

segment.source: Create an MDT application for each Windows Store app you want to deploy.
segment.target: Create an MDT application for each Windows Store app you want to deploy.

segment.source: You can deploy Windows Store apps by using sideloading, which allows you to use the Add-AppxPackage Windows PowerShell cmdlet to deploy the .appx files associated with the app (called provisioned apps).
segment.target: You can deploy Windows Store apps by using sideloading, which allows you to use the Add-AppxPackage Windows PowerShell cmdlet to deploy the .appx files associated with the app (called provisioned apps).

segment.source: Use this method to deploy up to 24 apps to Windows 10.
segment.target: Use this method to deploy up to 24 apps to Windows 10.

segment.source: Prior to sideloading the .appx files, obtain the Windows Store .appx files that you will use to deploy (sideload) the apps in your provisioning package.
segment.target: Prior to sideloading the .appx files, obtain the Windows Store .appx files that you will use to deploy (sideload) the apps in your provisioning package.

segment.source: For apps in Windows Store, you will need to obtain the .appx files from the app software vendor directly.
segment.target: For apps in Windows Store, you will need to obtain the .appx files from the app software vendor directly.

segment.source: If you are unable to obtain the .appx files from the app software vendor, then you or the students will need to install the apps on the student devices directly from Windows Store or Windows Store for Business.
segment.target: If you are unable to obtain the .appx files from the app software vendor, then you or the students will need to install the apps on the student devices directly from Windows Store or Windows Store for Business.

segment.source: If you have Intune, you can deploy Windows Store apps after you deploy Windows 10, as described in the Deploy apps by using Intune section.
segment.target: If you have Intune, you can deploy Windows Store apps after you deploy Windows 10, as described in the Deploy apps by using Intune section.

segment.source: This method provides granular deployment of Windows Store apps, and you can use it for ongoing management of Windows Store apps.
segment.target: This method provides granular deployment of Windows Store apps, and you can use it for ongoing management of Windows Store apps.

segment.source: This is the preferred method of deploying and managing Windows Store apps.
segment.target: This is the preferred method of deploying and managing Windows Store apps.

segment.source: In addition, you must prepare your environment for sideloading (deploying) Windows Store apps.
segment.target: In addition, you must prepare your environment for sideloading (deploying) Windows Store apps.

segment.source: For more information about how to:
segment.target: For more information about how to:

segment.source: Prepare your environment for sideloading, see Sideload LOB apps in Windows 10.
segment.target: Prepare your environment for sideloading, see Sideload LOB apps in Windows 10.

segment.source: Create an MDT application, see Create a New Application in the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: Create an MDT application, see Create a New Application in the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: Create MDT applications for Windows desktop apps
segment.target: Create MDT applications for Windows desktop apps

segment.source: You need to create an MDT application for each Windows desktop app you want to deploy.
segment.target: You need to create an MDT application for each Windows desktop app you want to deploy.

segment.source: You can obtain the Windows desktop apps from any source, but ensure that you have sufficient licenses for them.
segment.target: You can obtain the Windows desktop apps from any source, but ensure that you have sufficient licenses for them.

segment.source: To help reduce the effort needed to deploy Microsoft Office 2016 desktop apps, use the Office Deployment Tool, as described in Deploy Click-to-Run for Office 365 products by using the Office Deployment Tool.
segment.target: To help reduce the effort needed to deploy Microsoft Office 2016 desktop apps, use the Office Deployment Tool, as described in Deploy Click-to-Run for Office 365 products by using the Office Deployment Tool.

segment.source: If you have Intune, you can deploy Windows desktop apps after you deploy Windows 10, as described in the Deploy apps by using Intune section.
segment.target: If you have Intune, you can deploy Windows desktop apps after you deploy Windows 10, as described in the Deploy apps by using Intune section.

segment.source: This method provides granular deployment of Windows desktop apps, and you can use it for ongoing management of the apps.
segment.target: This method provides granular deployment of Windows desktop apps, and you can use it for ongoing management of the apps.

segment.source: This is the preferred method for deploying and managing Windows desktop apps.
segment.target: This is the preferred method for deploying and managing Windows desktop apps.

segment.source: Note: You can also deploy Windows desktop apps after you deploy Windows 10, as described in the Deploy apps by using Intune section.
segment.target: Note: You can also deploy Windows desktop apps after you deploy Windows 10, as described in the Deploy apps by using Intune section.

segment.source: For more information about how to create an MDT application for Window desktop apps, see Create a New Application in the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: For more information about how to create an MDT application for Window desktop apps, see Create a New Application in the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: Create task sequences.
segment.target: Create task sequences.

segment.source: You must create a separate task sequences for each Windows 10 edition, processor architecture, operating system upgrade process, and new operating system deployment process.
segment.target: You must create a separate task sequences for each Windows 10 edition, processor architecture, operating system upgrade process, and new operating system deployment process.

segment.source: Minimally, create a task sequence for each Windows 10 operating system you imported in Step 1—for example, (1) if you want to deploy Windows 10 Education to new devices or refresh existing devices with a new deployment of Windows 10 Education; (2) if you want to upgrade existing devices running Windows 8.1 or Windows 7 to Windows 10 Education; or (3) if you want to run deployments and upgrades for both 32 bit and 64 bit versions of Windows 10.
segment.target: Minimally, create a task sequence for each Windows 10 operating system you imported in Step 1—for example, (1) if you want to deploy Windows 10 Education to new devices or refresh existing devices with a new deployment of Windows 10 Education; (2) if you want to upgrade existing devices running Windows 8.1 or Windows 7 to Windows 10 Education; or (3) if you want to run deployments and upgrades for both 32 bit and 64 bit versions of Windows 10.

segment.source: To do so, you must create task sequences that will:
segment.target: To do so, you must create task sequences that will:

segment.source: Deploy Windows 10 Education 64-bit to devices.
segment.target: Deploy Windows 10 Education 64-bit to devices.

segment.source: Deploy Windows 10 Education 32-bit to devices.
segment.target: Deploy Windows 10 Education 32-bit to devices.

segment.source: Upgrade existing devices to Windows 10 Education 64-bit.
segment.target: Upgrade existing devices to Windows 10 Education 64-bit.

segment.source: Upgrade existing devices to Windows 10 Education 32-bit.
segment.target: Upgrade existing devices to Windows 10 Education 32-bit.

segment.source: Again, you will create the task sequences based on the operating systems that you imported in Step 1.
segment.target: Again, you will create the task sequences based on the operating systems that you imported in Step 1.

segment.source: For more information about how to create a task sequence, see Create a New Task Sequence in the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: For more information about how to create a task sequence, see Create a New Task Sequence in the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: Update the deployment share.
segment.target: Update the deployment share.

segment.source: Updating a deployment share generates the MDT boot images you use to initiate the Windows 10 deployment process.
segment.target: Updating a deployment share generates the MDT boot images you use to initiate the Windows 10 deployment process.

segment.source: You can configure the process to create 32 bit and 64 bit versions of the .iso and .wim files you can use to create bootable media or in Windows Deployment Services.
segment.target: You can configure the process to create 32 bit and 64 bit versions of the .iso and .wim files you can use to create bootable media or in Windows Deployment Services.

segment.source: For more information about how to update a deployment share, see Update a Deployment Share in the Deployment Workbench.
segment.target: For more information about how to update a deployment share, see Update a Deployment Share in the Deployment Workbench.

segment.source: Configure Window Deployment Services for MDT
segment.target: Configure Window Deployment Services for MDT

segment.source: You can use Windows Deployment Services in conjunction with MDT to automatically initiate boot images on target computers.
segment.target: You can use Windows Deployment Services in conjunction with MDT to automatically initiate boot images on target computers.

segment.source: These boot images can be Windows PE images (which you generated in Step 6 in Table 9) or custom images that can deploy operating systems directly to the target computers.
segment.target: These boot images can be Windows PE images (which you generated in Step 6 in Table 9) or custom images that can deploy operating systems directly to the target computers.

segment.source: To configure Windows Deployment Services for MDT
segment.target: To configure Windows Deployment Services for MDT

segment.source: Set up and configure Windows Deployment Services.
segment.target: Set up and configure Windows Deployment Services.

segment.source: Windows Deployment Services is a server role available in all Windows Server editions.
segment.target: Windows Deployment Services is a server role available in all Windows Server editions.

segment.source: You can enable the Windows Deployment Services server role on a new server or on any server running Windows Server in your institution.
segment.target: You can enable the Windows Deployment Services server role on a new server or on any server running Windows Server in your institution.

segment.source: For more information about how to perform this step, see the following resources:
segment.target: For more information about how to perform this step, see the following resources:

segment.target: Windows Deployment Services overview

segment.source: The Windows Deployment Services Help file, included in Windows Deployment Services
segment.target: The Windows Deployment Services Help file, included in Windows Deployment Services

segment.source: Windows Deployment Services Getting Started Guide for Windows Server 2012
segment.target: Windows Deployment Services Getting Started Guide for Windows Server 2012

segment.source: Add LTI boot images (Windows PE images) to Windows Deployment Services.
segment.target: Add LTI boot images (Windows PE images) to Windows Deployment Services.

segment.source: The LTI boot images (.wim files) that you will add to Windows Deployment Services are in the MDT deployment share.
segment.target: The LTI boot images (.wim files) that you will add to Windows Deployment Services are in the MDT deployment share.

segment.source: Locate the .wim files in the Boot subfolder in the deployment share.
segment.target: Locate the .wim files in the Boot subfolder in the deployment share.

segment.source: For more information about how to perform this step, see Add LTI Boot Images to Windows Deployment Services.
segment.target: For more information about how to perform this step, see Add LTI Boot Images to Windows Deployment Services.

segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: Now, Windows Deployment Services is ready to initiate the LTI deployment process in MDT.
segment.target: Now, Windows Deployment Services is ready to initiate the LTI deployment process in MDT.

segment.source: You have set up and configured Windows Deployment Services and added the LTI boot images, which you generated in the previous section, to Windows Deployment Services.
segment.target: You have set up and configured Windows Deployment Services and added the LTI boot images, which you generated in the previous section, to Windows Deployment Services.

segment.source: Now, you’re ready to prepare to manage the devices in your institution.
segment.target: Now, you’re ready to prepare to manage the devices in your institution.

segment.source: Prepare for device management
segment.target: Prepare for device management

segment.source: Before you deploy Windows 10 in your institution, you must prepare for device management.
segment.target: Before you deploy Windows 10 in your institution, you must prepare for device management.

segment.source: You will deploy Windows 10 in a configuration that complies with your requirements, but you want to help ensure that your deployments remain compliant.
segment.target: You will deploy Windows 10 in a configuration that complies with your requirements, but you want to help ensure that your deployments remain compliant.

segment.source: Select the management method
segment.target: Select the management method

segment.source: If you have only one device to configure, manually configuring that one device is tedious but possible.
segment.target: If you have only one device to configure, manually configuring that one device is tedious but possible.

segment.source: When you have multiple classrooms of devices to configure, however, manually configuring each device becomes overwhelming.
segment.target: When you have multiple classrooms of devices to configure, however, manually configuring each device becomes overwhelming.

segment.source: In addition, manually keeping an identical configuration on each device is virtually impossible as the number of devices in the school increases.
segment.target: In addition, manually keeping an identical configuration on each device is virtually impossible as the number of devices in the school increases.

segment.source: For a school, there are many ways to manage devices.
segment.target: For a school, there are many ways to manage devices.

segment.source: Table 10 lists the methods that this guide describes and recommends.
segment.target: Table 10 lists the methods that this guide describes and recommends.

segment.source: Use the information in Table 10 to determine which combination of management methods is right for your institution.
segment.target: Use the information in Table 10 to determine which combination of management methods is right for your institution.

segment.source: Table 10.
segment.target: Table 10.

segment.source: School management methods
segment.target: School management methods

segment.source: Method
segment.target: Method

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Group Policy
segment.target: Group Policy

segment.source: Group Policy is an integral part of AD DS and allows you to specify configuration settings for Windows 10 and previous versions of Windows.
segment.target: Group Policy is an integral part of AD DS and allows you to specify configuration settings for Windows 10 and previous versions of Windows.

segment.source: Select this method when you:
segment.target: Select this method when you:

segment.source: Want to manage institution-owned devices that are domain joined (personally owned devices are typically not domain joined).
segment.target: Want to manage institution-owned devices that are domain joined (personally owned devices are typically not domain joined).

segment.source: Want more granular control of device and user settings.
segment.target: Want more granular control of device and user settings.

segment.source: Have an existing AD DS infrastructure.
segment.target: Have an existing AD DS infrastructure.

segment.source: Typically manage on-premises devices.
segment.target: Typically manage on-premises devices.

segment.source: Intune
segment.target: Intune

segment.source: Intune is a cloud-based management system that allows you to specify configuration settings for Windows 10, previous versions of Windows, and other operating systems (such as iOS or Android).
segment.target: Intune is a cloud-based management system that allows you to specify configuration settings for Windows 10, previous versions of Windows, and other operating systems (such as iOS or Android).

segment.source: Intune is a subscription-based cloud service that integrates with Office 365 and Azure AD.
segment.target: Intune is a subscription-based cloud service that integrates with Office 365 and Azure AD.

segment.source: Select this method when you:
segment.target: Select this method when you:

segment.source: Want to manage institution-owned and personal devices (does not require that the device be domain joined).
segment.target: Want to manage institution-owned and personal devices (does not require that the device be domain joined).

segment.source: Don’t require the level of granular control over device and user settings (compared to Group Policy).
segment.target: Don’t require the level of granular control over device and user settings (compared to Group Policy).

segment.source: Don’t have an existing AD DS infrastructure.
segment.target: Don’t have an existing AD DS infrastructure.

segment.source: Need to manage devices regardless of where they are (on or off premises).
segment.target: Need to manage devices regardless of where they are (on or off premises).

segment.source: Can manage a required setting only by using Intune.
segment.target: Can manage a required setting only by using Intune.

segment.source: The advantages of this method are:
segment.target: The advantages of this method are:

segment.source: You can manage institution-owned and personal devices.
segment.target: You can manage institution-owned and personal devices.

segment.source: It doesn’t require that devices be domain joined.
segment.target: It doesn’t require that devices be domain joined.

segment.source: It doesn’t require any on-premises infrastructure.
segment.target: It doesn’t require any on-premises infrastructure.

segment.source: It can manage devices regardless of their location (on or off premises).
segment.target: It can manage devices regardless of their location (on or off premises).

segment.source: The disadvantages of this method are:
segment.target: The disadvantages of this method are:

segment.source: Carries an additional cost for subscription.
segment.target: Carries an additional cost for subscription.

segment.source: Doesn’t have a granular level control over device and user settings (compared to Group Policy).
segment.target: Doesn’t have a granular level control over device and user settings (compared to Group Policy).

segment.source: Select Microsoft-recommended settings
segment.target: Select Microsoft-recommended settings

segment.source: Microsoft has several recommended settings for educational institutions.
segment.target: Microsoft has several recommended settings for educational institutions.

segment.source: Table 11 lists them, provides a brief description of why you need to configure them, and recommends methods for configuring the settings.
segment.target: Table 11 lists them, provides a brief description of why you need to configure them, and recommends methods for configuring the settings.

segment.source: Review the settings in Table 11 and evaluate their relevancy to your institution.
segment.target: Review the settings in Table 11 and evaluate their relevancy to your institution.

segment.source: Use the information to help you determine whether you need to configure the setting and which method you will use to do so.
segment.target: Use the information to help you determine whether you need to configure the setting and which method you will use to do so.

segment.target: At the end, you will have a list of settings that you want to apply to the Windows 10 devices and know which management method you will use to configure the settings.

segment.source: To configure Group Policy settings
segment.target: To configure Group Policy settings

segment.source: Create a Group Policy object (GPO) that will contain the Group Policy settings by completing the steps in Create a new Group Policy object.
segment.target: Create a Group Policy object (GPO) that will contain the Group Policy settings by completing the steps in Create a new Group Policy object.

segment.source: Configure the settings in the GPO by completing the steps in Edit a Group Policy object.
segment.target: Configure the settings in the GPO by completing the steps in Edit a Group Policy object.

segment.source: Link the GPO to the appropriate AD DS site, domain, or organizational unit by completing the steps in Link a Group Policy object to a site, domain, or organizational unit.
segment.target: Link the GPO to the appropriate AD DS site, domain, or organizational unit by completing the steps in Link a Group Policy object to a site, domain, or organizational unit.
